description:
SMU SCIS alumnus Quan Heng Lim discussed the cyber security trends in Southeast Asia and his role in educating the next generation of cyber security professionals.

📽 https://bit.ly/38hoTUP

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #Cybersecurity #SMUSCIS #SgSMUSCIS

Have you ever wondered how a website like YouTube knows what you want and like? E-commerce websites use a recommender system that employs artificial intelligence and data science. It is a data filtering tool using machine learning algorithms to recommend the most relevant items to a particular user to increase user engagement and drive purchases.

This is an area of research that SMU SCIS Associate Professor Hady W. Lauw is working on. Learn more at smu.sg/predicted-recommendations

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #ArtificialIntelligence #ComputerScience #DataScience #RecommenderSystems #MachineLearning #Algorithm #SMUSCIS #SgSMUSCIS

Over the past weekend, Whitehat Society (@smuwhitehats) organised its annual flagship event, Whitehacks 2022 held across a span of 2 days from 19 - 20 March! For this year's iteration, we had over 350 students from various Junior Colleges and High Schools joining us to explore and learn more about cybersecurity.

Day 1 commenced with an Opening Address from the Dean of SMU School of Computing and Information Systems, Dr. Pang Hwee Hwa. Following which, students got to learn more about various opportunities and interact with various industry professionals from Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT), GovTech Singapore and Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) through Zoom sharing sessions and Discord villages.

The highlight of the event, an 8-hour Capture-the-Flag competition was held on Day 2. It began with a flurry of challenges being first blooded by various teams within the first hour alone! The competition remained very intense throughout the entire duration and we were heartened to see all the participating teams giving it their all as they battled for the top prizes.

We would also like to express our heartfelt thanks to our sponsors, Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT), GovTech Singapore, Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) and Mandiant for supporting us in this event. We would also like to thank Kenneth T. from Alt Tab Labs for helping us to manage the CTF infrastructure throughout the entire duration of the competition.

Thank you everyone and we look forward to seeing you again next year!

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SMUSCIS #SGSMUSCIS

Since 2011, SMU’s Dato’ Kho Hui Meng Career Centre annually selects three undergrads to receive the Ruth Chiang Outstanding Intern of the Year Award, as a tribute to undergrads who have gone above and beyond in their internships, exhibited exceptional work ethic, and upheld the University’s CIRCLE values, all while carrying the SMU brand with pride during their work stints.

Read the full story to find out how winner Daniel Lim Wai Kiat, first runner-up Giles Chang Chee Song – both from SCIS – and second runner-up Tan Zhi Hui from SMU School of Social Sciences, raised the bar with their tenacity and adaptability as they refused to let Covid-19 dampen their internship experience.

🔗 smu.sg/interns-shine-from-home

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SMUSCIS #SgSMUSCIS

Gestural recognition is a hot topic for researchers and the technology can be accurately deployed using a solar panel, according to a project co-authored by SMU Assistant Professor Dong Ma.

Read More: smu.sg/controlling-devices-wave-hand

Ergonomic furniture brands ErgoTune and EverDesk+ founded by SMU SCIS alumnus Joshua Chan (featured left) and his team, have been fully acquired by e-commerce roll up startup Una Brands in a deal worth over eight figures, making it one of the largest acquisitions of Singapore-based direct-to-consumer brands!

🔗 Source: https://bit.ly/3pK8Ncd

#SgSMUSCIS #SMUSCIS #SMUAlumni

With the pervasive use of technology across economy, society and polity, the demand for computing talent, including software engineers, has been increasing in Singapore and globally and is expected to remain high in the foreseeable future.

Starting August 2022, SMU School of Computing and Information Systems (SCIS) will be launching the Bachelor of Science (Software Engineering) SkillsFuture Work-Study degree programme which combines classroom-learning with structured on-the-job training. It features a rigorous 52-week apprenticeship where undergraduate students work in development teams under the mentorship of professional software engineers. The collaboration with the programme’s first anchor partner - Government Technology Agency of Singapore (GovTech) – was formalised with the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding by Professor Pang Hwee Hwa, Dean of SCIS, and Mr D N Prasad, Senior Director of Strategy, People & Organisation, GovTech.

🔗 Press release: smu.sg/news-software-engineering-wsdeg

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SoftwareEngineering #Apprenticeship #Undergraduate #SMUSCIS #SgSMUSCIS

Whitehacks 2022, an annual flagship event organised by our special interest group Whitehat Society (@smuwhitehats), conducted a training workshop for over 200 students from various Junior Colleges on 26 February 2022. In-house trainers Kenneth Toh, Yong Jiun Lew and Hoon Kai-Wei went through some Blue Team and Red Team topics including memory forensics, network traffic analysis and local file inclusion.

The main event will be held on the 19 and 20 March 2022, during which participants will have an opportunity to network with the event sponsors namely - Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT), GovTech, Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA), and compete in a Capture-The-Flag competition to win attractive prizes!

According to the latest Joint Autonomous Universities Graduate Employment Survey (JAUGES), Information Systems graduates earned the highest salary with a mean monthly salary of $4,906, as compared to the 2020 cohort’s $4,683. The median gross monthly salary is $5,000, up from $4,542 in 2020. Those with Cum Laude or better earned a mean gross monthly salary of $5,499 and a median gross salary of $5,350.

🔗 Source: smu.sg/new-ges-2022

Interested students can register before 25 February 2022!

Reposted @govtechsg ••••• Building inclusive products is a team sport. 💪 It happens when leaders and their teams come together to ensure everyone gets access to their product. 

For example, software engineering teams need to take time to understand how persons with disabilities (PWDs) interact with technology, then design and test their services around their needs.

🟢 Join Zui Young (SCIS Alumnus, Graduating Class of 2015) in our upcoming #InsideGovTech Live Chat to find out more about how we are Fostering Inclusion By Design. 

🗓: 23 Feb (Wed), 12pm
📹: LinkedIn Live, RSVP with the link in bio!

#Inclusive #TechForPublicGood #GovTechSG

In the first of a five-week askST series on university education, senior education correspondent Sandra Davie addressed questions on university places – in particular, the sought-after spots for computer degree studies. In response to a parent's questions on what to consider when deciding between the various computing programmes offered across the different universities and asked for more information about computing degrees in SMU, SMU School of Computing and Information Systems and Lee Kong Chian Chair Professor of Computer Science Pang Hwee Hwa said the School currently offers four undergraduate computing programmes that target different job roles demanded by employers. He shared about the different focus of SMU's Computer Science degree; Information Systems degree; the BSc in (Computing and Law) in partnership with the SMU Yong Pung How School of Law; and a new computing degree in software engineering. Prof Pang advised students to first decide which area they would like to specialise in, and then consider the unique value propositions of SMU and the computing degrees it offers.

🔗 https://bit.ly/3ArPY1l

The 2021 challenge to develop technology-based solutions to reimagine learning experiences, in line with Singapore's focus on building diversity in schools and lifelong learning with digitalisation as a main tool, was clinched by The Circus, an all-female student team from SMU and NTU. The platform that SMU students Jennifer Poernomo, Jeanette Lee and Michelle Leong, and NTU student Ng Yan Qing are developing to connect students to study groups and matches tutors to students received the most appreciation from a panel of four judges at the second annual Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) Sustainathon Singapore on Wednesday. 

The platform focuses on reimagining learning experiences. It also has a question-and-answer forum and provides study materials to connect students virtually. "It was very hard for us to make friends in school with online classes, where all we know of our classmates are their names on a screen. We hope that our platform can start a culture of peer-to-peer learning during the Covid-19 pandemic," said Michelle.

🔗 https://bit.ly/3IkUf9V

SMU School of Computing and Information Systems graduand Goh Jin Qiang, who graduated with a Bachelor of Science (Information Systems), shared about his interest in video games which made him decide to study information technology at the Institute of Technical Education (ITE). Encouraged by an ITE lecturer, he found the motivation to study, and went on to polytechnic, where he was awarded a scholarship by the Infocomm Media Development Authority to further his studies at university. Jin Qiang is currently a System Analyst at Urban Redevelopment Authority.

SMU kicked off six days of graduation celebration for the Class of 2020 on December 15 at the Opening Ceremony of SMU Commencement 2020. The in-person ceremony, which was graced by Guest-of-Honour Dr Ng Eng Hen, Minister for Defence, was held on SMU campus with 258 persons in attendance. In his speech, Dr Ng pointed out that the employment prospects of SMU’s graduates are good. Nearly 60 per cent of SMU’s 2020 graduates found full-time employment before graduation, and 94 per cent of them found full-time employment within six months of graduation.

Organised by Singapore Maritime Foundation’s MSC Office together with three maritime companies – Eastport Maritime, Kanda and Torvald Klaveness, the inaugural Maritime Singapore Connect (MSC) Maritime Digital Challenge aims to connect tertiary students with a passion for technology to the digital transformation taking place in the maritime industry.

The grand finals held on 13 November saw Singapore Management University’s Team Klaver emerge as the Grand Champion for the Torvald Klaveness Challenge. The team comprised of the following students:
- Farm Jia Jia, Lee Kong Chian School of Business (LKCSB), Year 4
- Ryan Tan Zheng Jie, LKCSB, Year 1
- Gabrielle Soh, LKCSB, Year 3
- Caleb Cheong, School of Computing and Information Systems (SCIS), Year 2
- Brandon Christopher, SCIS, Year 2

“Seeing our research efforts translate to useful things is a gratifying experience,” said Associate Professor Hady Lauw at SMU School of Computing and Information Systems, also co-founder of ThriftCity.

Initially conceptualised as a research prototype two years ago, ThriftCity was born out of Prof Hady’s National Research Foundation (NRF)-funded research project. With the use of the AI framework for data mining & machine learning, ThriftCity can source & compare similar products across the Internet.

Dean of the School of Computing and Information Systems (SCIS) Professor Pang Hwee Hwa said, “The School of Computing and Information Systems has been increasing our intake of undergraduates and postgraduates over the years. We have launched and refreshed our education programmes in response to emerging technologies and market demands in order to stay relevant to the industry. Our programmes have gained a reputation for quality and rigour among employers and prospective students. They are confident that SCIS graduates are industry-ready, innovation-enabled solution developers who are trained to use emerging technologies such as Financial Technology, Artificial Intelligence and the Internet-of-Things to develop solutions that create value to business and society.”

SMU SCIS alumna Lim Li Xuan, a technology analyst at Accenture, also shares why she took up computing and information systems at SMU and how she hopes to contribute to society using her computing skills.

Congratulations to Professor Jing Jiang for making it to the Singapore 100 Women In Tech (SG100WIT) 2021 list! 🎉

Jing is a respected researcher and academic in natural language processing (NLP). She has published over 100 papers in many top-tier conferences and journals and chaired various academic conferences. Her work is in the application of NLP, proposing new solutions for a range of areas including information extraction, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, social media analysis, and most recently question answering.

Her research areas broadly fall into four directions: question answering, social media analysis, information extraction and domain adaptation.

A current topic she is researching on is the study of AI models especially for visual and verbal question-answer systems. This is necessary to enable machines to work together with people interactively through natural communications for joint problem solving.

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SG100WIT #SGWomeninTech

Vertical farming, tracking of water usage and visualisation of vehicle emissions – these are the winning ideas that had emerged from the inaugural Code for Cities hackathon organised by SMU Anthill Society (@smu.anthillsociety) in collaboration with Surbana Jurong Private Limited from 12 July to 6 August 2021.

The theme of the competition was Environmental Sustainability & Resiliency. Participants had to derive data analytics insights from relevant open-sourced data sets and develop solutions to a specific smart city challenge they have identified.

Vertical farming, tracking of water usage and visualisation of vehicle emissions – these are the winning ideas that had emerged from the inaugural Code for Cities hackathon organised by SMU Anthill Society (@smu.anthillsociety) in collaboration with Surbana Jurong Private Limited from 12 July to 6 August 2021.

The theme of the competition was Environmental Sustainability & Resiliency. Participants had to derive data analytics insights from relevant open-sourced data sets and develop solutions to a specific smart city challenge they have identified.

🔗 smu.sg/developing-smart-solutions-smart-cities

Lin Fengru’s (BSc (ISM) 2011) love for cheese-making led her on a hunt around the world to support her passion. In the process, she found her calling. Team QWERTY, which consisted of Lee Yu Hao and Aw Khai Loong from SMU School of Computing and Information Systems, and Natalia Mai Do Ngoc, Galen Ong and Ezra Lim from SMU Yong Pung How School of Law (@sgsmuyphsl), were crowned overall champions at the SMU Legal Innovation and Technology (LIT) Hackathon 2021 (@smulit.2021) which took place virtually this year from 13 – 15 August.

The team recognised the challenges of navigating the legal system for the average person on the street today, and conceptualised “LowerTheBar”, an application that leverages on speech recognition, deep learning and an AR experience to provide applicants with a seamless, accurate and immersive experience to help lay people gain access to justice.

🔗 https://smu.sg/smu-lit-hackathon-2021

Singapore Management University kicked off three days of graduation celebration for the Class of 2021 today at the SMU Virtual Commencement 2021. Specially curated by the University and held virtually for the second time in light of the Covid-19 situation, the event aims to commemorate an important milestone of the graduates’ journey with SMU.
 
This year, SMU will be presenting pioneer graduates from the following programmes:
- BSc (Information Systems) Smart-City Management and Technology major
- Master of Science in Computing
- Doctor of Philosophy in Business (Operations Management)

🔗 Full Article: smu.sg/smu-scis-commencement-2021

Team Oats, comprising of our fellow SMU students Dante Liew, Ong Wei Jie, Teo Eng Siang, Soh Wan Ting and NTU student Jordan Ang, took up the challenge at the "Build On, ASEAN 2021" Hackathon, to address the negative chat experience on Carousell's platform.

The team’s proposal is centered on the notion that the chat experience faced by a user makes or breaks the deal. Hence, they developed an application with sentiment analysis function that is able to detect negative languages as well as low-ball offers, to ensure deals between a buyer and seller are handled amicably.

Do check out the links to their application codebase:
Frontend (React): https://lnkd.in/gKbHCpyg
Backend (Laravel): https://lnkd.in/gyDx4mf2
Video demo: https://lnkd.in/guWsmJX7

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SMUSCIS

SMU School of Computing and Information Systems student Joshua Tseng who was a recipient of the UBS Promise award last year was featured on Today news. Despite his deteriorating eyesight, Tseng has thrived in the field of public speaking, advocating for the visually impaired community. He is particularly passionate about the importance of accessibility, a topic he talks about in schools and events such as TEDxYouth. Tseng has also spoken at a Microsoft event last year, where he emphasised the importance of accessibility for the visually impaired.

🔗 Source: https://bit.ly/3y9Ojvo

Our heartiest congratulations to Alumnus Alvin Poh (BSc (ISM), 2010) on the launch of ‘Super Scaling’ book! 🎉 

Reposted @alvinpohofficial •••••• Why Is Scaling A Business Hard?

This is a question I frequently asked myself when I was still starting out. Scaling is hard because of one’s perspective. Oftentimes, business owners focus on the wrong things when scaling… coming in with the intention of finding more clients and buyers (even worse, thinking of how to SELL your business immediately) is the wrong perspective.

Trust me, this is not the way to go.

“Okay Alvin…but exactly what should we focus on?”

In order to scale, one must go back to the basics! It may seem counter-intuitive…but think about it. How will you see exponential growth when you haven’t established a STRONG FOUNDATION?

Your foundation should be strong enough to withstand the growth you want to achieve. 

In my book, I’ll be talking about the 5 PILLARS you should focus on in order to scale, the same exact system I used for scaling my business to $30M! 
.
.
.
.
.
#businesshelp #scaleyourbusiness #buildyourempire #gottastayfocused #onlinebusinesscoach #growthmindset #entrepreneurcoach #businessinspiration #businessmindset101 #business101 #businessgoal #businessmentor #millionairemindset #millionairementor #businessmindset #onlinebusiness #thesuccessclub #entrepreneur101 #entrepreneurmotivation #businessleadership #successcoach #motivationmonday #successquotes #hustleharder #businessquotes #successmindset #hustlehard #mindsetiseverything #mindsetcoach #selfimprovement

Your foundation should be strong enough to withstand the growth you want to achieve. 

In my book, I’ll be talking about the 5 PILLARS you should focus on in order to scale, the same exact system I used for scaling my business to $30M!

Sharing the success story of our alumnus Asher Chua! Reposted @access.sgp •••••
For this week’s #journeytowardsuccess, we spoke to Asher Chua, who works in Business Development at Impact. As a teenager, Asher was disinterested in school and underwent a rebellious phase which led to him dropping out at 15. Without having an O-Level certificate he struggled to find a stable job and went from one part-time job to another. Eventually, he decided to take his O-levels privately which helped him earn a place at RP pursuing Mobile Software Development. Despite, previously never enjoying studying his passion for tech helped see him through poly and even spurred him on to continue studying a course in a similar space at SMU. 

While Asher’s journey is unconventional it led to him discovering his passion and his career interests. Do read on to find out more about his journey! 

 #careerjourney #entrepreneurship #daretoleap #socialmobility #nonprofit

SMU School of Computing and Information Systems alumnus Alvin Poh sold off Vodien Internet Solutions – a highly successful Internet company which he co-founded 17 years ago – for $30 million about three years ago. Besides that, Alvin donated $250,000 to his alma mater SMU, to set up a scholarship in his name. Last year, when the Covid-19 pandemic was raging, he decided to set up Super Scaling to share his entrepreneurial experience and assist companies or individuals to quickly expand their business and achieve success.

📰 Source: https://bit.ly/3cLWup2

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SMUSCIS

SMU Associate Professor of Psychology Chi-Ying Cheng and SMU Associate Professor of Computer Science Shih-Fen Cheng will be conducting the world's first longitudinal study to ascertain how the female-to-male gender ratios, as well as the presence of female role models affect the level of gender-professional identity integration (G-PII) – an identity construct that is critical for women to transition and position themselves for success in a male-dominated sector like STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). The research study is designed as a quasi-experiment and will be conducted over 15 months. The sample will include 200 first year students who are enrolled in SMU's School of Computing and Information Systems.

🔗 Read the full article: https://bit.ly/3vT5mRC

Artificial Intelligence has been the talk of the town for the last decade and remains a hot topic among not only developers, engineers and data scientists, but also entrepreneurs and government bodies. It is a term you hear often and you might not realise it - AI has integrated into our lives as well. 

Let’s hear from Ke Xin, who is currently majoring in IT Solution Development (AI) at the School of Computing and Information Systems to tell us more about the major. 

What made you choose to take IT Solution Development (AI) as a major? 
I personally find AI something that intrigues me. Applications of AI can be found in our daily lives, such as Google Maps, Instagram's explore page, Netflix's recommendation, Apple's Face ID, and many more. Ever wonder how Google Maps works? How does it show you different paths you can take to reach your destination, how does it know the estimated duration of the trip, how does it ensure that the path you take will definitely bring you to the destination? The answers to these questions were previously obtained by flipping manually through the street directory, whereas now, with AI, it can be simply acquired with a few clicks away on your smartphone. 
 
What would you share with others who are considering to take AI as a major? 
I would encourage everyone who has an interest in AI and wants to make an impact on society in the future to go for it. It will not be easy, but it will definitely be a fulfilling experience! 
 
Any memorable AI-related modules or experiences you have undergone in SMU? 
Though it has only been a semester into our specialized tracks, and I have only taken an Introduction to Artificial Intelligence CS420, I was immediately captivated, and it has enhanced my interest in AI and the relevant fields. Through this module, I was taught the basics of AI such as Neural Networks and Natural Language Processing (NLP), but of course, I am aware that slides, textbooks, and theories are far from sufficient. Thus, my professor has also gone through Python and Jupyter Notebook files to ensure that we gain some exposure to what is expected in the real working world.

Discover for yourself how incoming students of SMU School of Computing and Information Systems Lydia Tan and Jenna Cheo decided that SMU is the choice for them.

Read the full article: smu.sg/why-smu-university

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #SMUSCIS

SCIS alumnus Zhu Juntao and his co-founder officially launched Hodlnaut, a crypto borrowing and lending platform, which lets customers deposit their cryptocurrencies and earn up to 10 per cent interest rate, in 2019. To date, Hodlnaut has over 5,000 users trusting them to manage over US$300 million in cryptocurrencies. This is 100 times more than what they were managing a year ago, and an even higher amount compared to what they launched with. The company is currently awaiting the licensing outcome from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

We're back again with Stephanie, who wants to share why Prof. George Wong is her favourite SMU Professor!
 
Hi! 👋🏻 I’m Stephanie Winata, a Year 1 student from the School of Computing and Information Systems. When I’m not coding, I’m hosting with SMU Broadcasting & Entertainment and dancing with SMU Caderas Latinas. 
 
Amongst SMU’s many outstanding professors, my favourite this semester is Prof George Wong, teaching COR3001: Big Questions. He pushes us to think more deeply about the world we live in, encouraging us to chase our curiosities and never stop questioning why things are the way they are. Teaching about the local and global interactions of our world, Prof George skilfully breaks down the complex relations of the world around us into simple analogies, never failing to blow our minds every lesson. Filled with lively debates about Kpop, history and culture, his classes are the perfect way to end the week.

Here at SMU, we are huge advocates of a holistic University education. But what's in a name? Let Jodie, a student who has benefitted from SMU's holistic approach to education tell you all about it!

Q: Introduce yourself (name, year, course)
A: Hey there! My name is Jodie Ethelda, a Year 3 student pursuing a double degree in Information Systems (Artificial Intelligence) and Economics (Data Science & Analytics).

Q: Briefly describe your journey in SMU so far (majors, ccas)
A: My journey in SMU has been wonderful and fruitful. I was given the flexibility to take any double degree combination of my choice, which allowed me to pursue the fields which I found my passion for. SMU also offered me with meaning experiences for global exposure, where I was blessed to have been able to visit India for my OCSP and work with clients located in Germany for my study mission projects. 

Q: How has SMU supported your pursuit of a holistic University so far? 
A: After enrolling into SMU, I found myself to have grown both cognitively and socially. The SMU-X modules I have taken exposed me to working with both MNCs and SME clients, allowing me to learn from real-world issues faced by my clients within their industry as well as improve my people-management skills. Being part of the SMU Ambassadorial Corps has also widened my perspectives and expanded my network. Most importantly, the abundance of group projects in SMU has also attained me irreplaceable friends that have supported me through my SMU life.

#SMU #Singapore #smuadmissions #DiscoverSMU #undergraduate #students #university #studentlife #college #education

We caught up with Amelia Tay, a first year student, to hear what she has to say about her decision to join the School of Computing and Information Systems (SCIS):

“I think that the SMU School of Computing and Information Systems @sgsmuscis is really unique! Initially, I was apprehensive about applying to SCIS as I did not have a coding background. However, the struggle and growth with my peers in SMU was what kept me going and pulled me through. I chose SMU mainly because of the degree of flexibility SMU programmes offer that isn’t as distinct in other universities. Here, I am not restricted to do anything I wish to pursue – with the exception of each day being limited to 24 hours.

Nonetheless, I’ve enjoyed a vibrant student life thus far – being a part of SMU FIDES, SMU Badminton Club, Growth-X Consulting as well as The Mentoring Circle have blessed me with good friends, opportunities, and a place to call home whenever I am on campus. It doesn’t hurt that SMU’s facilities are pretty and with plenty of wall sockets around too!”
 
#smuadmissions #undergraduate #DiscoverSMU #studentlife #sgsmu #smusg #smulife #meetourfirstyear

A team of SMU students, calling themselves "Legal Kaki", jumped in to support migrant workers who are concerned they will not be paid their usual wages. SMU students Shukrina Salam and Sambhavi Rajangam (SMU Law), Joey Chung (SMU Economics) and Abhyuday Samadder (SMU Information Systems), have developed an online salary calculator, called CalculAID, to help them assess their salary claims. It also provides guidance on the claims process.

Legal Kaki was formed in 2019 at the SMU Legal Innovation and Technology club's inaugural hackathon. The team presented solutions to increase access to justice across the various areas of law in Singapore and emerged second runners-up in the competition. Since then, the four have been working closely with the Singapore Academy of Law to improve access to justice related to employment matters.

🔗 Full Article: https://bit.ly/3bBPWdb

#ComputingAtSMU #DigitalTransformation #LegalTech

[Alumni Story] In May 2019, following a rise in fake academic credentials, three individuals - Derrick Lee (SIS 2020), Gwendolyn Goh (SIS 2020) and Shaun John Cheetham (SIS 2020), founded Accredify. The team resolved to create an affordable solution that would revolutionise the world of identity and document management, and protect individuals from these fraudulent acts. Applying Accredify's technology, they created a robust system that can be easily permutated and customised for clients in various industries. 

One such instance was the collaboration with MOH and MOM in July 2020. Accredify developed a solution to verify COVID-19 discharge memos in the FWMOMCare mobile app. This helped to expedite their re-entry in the workforce. As of 31 Oct 2020, it has been verified more than 2 million times across Singapore! 

Reflecting on their success, they credited SMU that helped nurture their leadership and entrepreneurship skills. As Shaun shared, “Learning from professors who have a platitude of industry knowledge and experience certainly helped in ensuring that questions never went unanswered, and best practices shared.” The support had given them a kick-start into the business world. 

Learn more about Accredify here: https://accredify.io/ 

#sgSMUalumni #SMUAlumniStory #ComputingAtSMU

Receiving the award from Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong at the Goh Chok Tong Enable Awards Ceremony held at the Istana on Thursday, 3 December 2020, Year 3 SIS Student Joshua Tseng is one of sixteen individuals who were honoured at the event.

When asked about his SMU experience, Joshua said, “Making the jump from my studies for a Diploma in Marketing at Temasek Polytechnic to a Bachelor’s in Information Systems at SMU was a big leap on its own, and studying an IT-related course for a person with a vision impairment further adds its own set of challenges. I’m thankful I’ve been able to make it this far both based on my own merit and with the support of family, friends, mentors, faculty, and other staff from SIS and DII – I wouldn’t be here without any of these people.”

This giving season, SMU Alumni Giving (@sgsmualumni) is celebrating SMU’s 20th Anniversary by inviting all alumni to participate in the #LeaveYourMark campaign! With a minimum of $100, your personalised message or quote will be engraved on a commemorative plaque (and installed permanently in SIS’s Seminar Room 2.1) to encourage your juniors! All proceeds raised will go towards the SMU Bursary Fund that aids financially-challenged students; your gift will also receive a 2.5 times tax deduction. Join your peers in giving back in a meaningful way, and commemorate your time in SMU with a fun, quirky, or memorable quote! 

Leave Your Mark today: https://giving.smu.edu.sg/giving-campaigns/leave-your-mark
 
#sgSMUalumni #SMUAlumniGiving

Meet Our First Year: Chong Zhan Han

First-year student Zhan Han, formerly from Temasek Junior College, is an SMU School of Information Systems (SIS) Achievements Scholar studying Computer Science. He’s also interested in exploring possible 2nd majors such as IT Solution Management and Entrepreneurship – but he has plenty of time to decide!

“I chose SMU because of the city campus! It is located right smack in the middle of town, making it really accessible. I also appreciate that the faculty and staff members at SMU are extremely helpful and approachable, making it easy for students to seek help. Lastly, with the Computer Science programme in SMU, students are equipped with both technical rigour and strong business acumen, giving them the best of both worlds. So, these are some reasons why I joined SMU and I certainly hope to see you here soon!!”

- Zhan Han

 #smuadmissions #discoverSMU #sgsmu #studentexperience @smu.sis

Beatrice is a Year 4 student majoring in 𝗦𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘁-𝗖𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗧𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗼𝗹𝗼𝗴𝘆. 🏢💡

Career Champions was a platform for her to share her experiences and learn from others. She encourages us to step up and take on opportunities in order to grow and develop ourselves. 🤗 As an experienced senior who has interned as a 𝗗𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗰𝗵 𝗖𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗲 (𝗟𝗔𝗥𝗖), she has a few tips to share with us:

“It is necessary to set your own goals and constantly retrospect. Most importantly don't forget to enjoy your struggle and growth.”
--
Swipe left to read more, and check out her full story (link in bio)! 
--

His phenomenal experiences in diverse sectors, from technical jobs in Data Engineering to more business-related roles in finance sectors, have leveraged his knowledge and expertise from his majors. 👨‍💻 Recently, he completed his internship at 𝗔𝗜𝗔 𝗦𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗽𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝘀 𝗮 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗥𝗲-𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻. 

Wende sees Career Champions as a community dedicated to helping SMU students find the right career path, and here’s what he would like to share with us. ✌️

“In any internship remember to:
1. Ask Questions
2. Be Humble 
3. Listen to your colleagues”

His phenomenal experiences in diverse sectors, from technical jobs in Data Engineering to more business-related roles in finance sectors, have leveraged his knowledge and expertise from his majors. 👨‍💻 Recently, he completed his internship at 𝗔𝗜𝗔 𝗦𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗽𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝘀 𝗮 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗥𝗲-𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻. 

Wende sees Career Champions as a community dedicated to helping SMU students find the right career path, and here’s what he would like to share with us. ✌️

“In any internship remember to:
1. Ask Questions
2. Be Humble 
3. Listen to your colleagues”
--
Swipe left to read more, and check out his full story (link in bio)! 
--

Congrats to Team Badoop (consisting of Jarvin Ong from SUTD, and SIS alumni Jolene Teo, Zul Yang and Gabriel Manuel Sidik) for the splendid achievement at the AWS Singapore Hackdays Online 2020! This year takes on the challenge to accelerate South-East Asia's digitalization by building new solutions addressing four topics - sustainability, learning & development, automation and security. Using Amazon Web Services, the team showcases CANARI – a disaster relief solution that guides victim to safety and provides medical visibility across to health workers. 
_

“We are pleased to kick off virtually this student project with 36 bright future talents from Singapore Management University. A team of SIS students – comprising of Patrick Lim Yan Hong, Vinnie Chu Yi Xuan, Ong Yan Kai, Jane Seah Hing Kid, and Lim Pei Xuan - beat more than 370 teams in Singapore to clinch the first position at the SCDF x IBM Lifesavers' Innovation Challenge: Call For Code 2020!

The proposed solution, called Dr Watson To The Rescue, utilises smart infrastructure such as sensors embedded within buildings to increase the efficiency and safety of emergency evacuation and rescue. The system can be deployed to any building as long as they have the infrastructure required, including WiFi, CCTV cameras and smoke/fire sensors.
 
📰 Read More at https://smu.sg/scdf-ibm-challenge-2020
_

“In SIS, we are a small but tight-knit community. In this collaborative and helpful community, I have formed genuine friendships. SIS is home to many exceptional mentors, individuals who go out of their way to support my personal growth and push me to the best of my ability. Not to mention the SIS curriculum equips us with industry relevant technical skills, in-depth business knowledge, as well as interpersonal skills that would give us a head start in career development. All the best and happy graduation to the Class of 2020!” – Ong Li Ting, Class of 2020 Graduand, SMU School of Information Systems

SIS alumnus Marcus Wee is the founder of Aftershock PC (@aftershockpc), a homegrown company that specialises in custom-built, boutique PCs at accessible price points. When asked about his choice to study Information Systems at SMU, he professed that he “didn’t really put thought into it, but it turned out to be a good choice” as SMU focuses on presentation skills which he was lacking in. Feeling inspired by his gaming PC buying experience during his five-month student exchange at the University of Waterloo in Toronto, Canada during his second year of university, he presented the idea of Aftershock in his technopreneurship class when he returned to SMU, and partnered with his classmate to start Aftershock PC in 2012.

Source: Vulcan Post

_

SIS Associate Professor Tan Hwee Pink is the co-principal investigator of a study which developed a novel and promising way to gauge seniors' cognitive functions by using a network of sensors to track their memory, movements and sleep patterns over a period of time. Describing the study results as promising, Assoc Prof Tan said the pilot study – the first of its kind in Singapore – is noteworthy given Singapore's rapidly ageing population and the growing number of elderly diagnosed with dementia. He added that the researchers wanted to detect mild cognitive impairment at an early stage, which could give a senior the best chance to reverse the impairment or at least delay the deterioration with appropriate treatment.

_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #Dementia #SMUResearch #SMUInsights

SIS alumna Clarissa Goh is currently the Chief of Staff at Mighty Bear, a Singapore-based studio building multiplayer online mobile games. She shared that back in university and at work, there is generally a trend of fewer number of females studying and working in the IT sector. She noted that in the typically male-dominated IT industry, males have dictated the industry culture as well as the type of behaviour deemed acceptable, and jokes that are usually not taken seriously amongst them, may be viewed as discriminatory or inappropriate, when a female is present. 🔗 Source: https://bit.ly/3dpqvtf

Knowing that the industry he has chosen is a fast-paced one where “learning never stops”, SMU 2019 DBS Bank School Valedictorian in Information Systems Tan Kee Hock focused not only on studying the curriculum well, but also learning how to learn better. During his time in SMU, Kee Hock cultivated the habit of applying what he learnt in class into his daily life when trying to internalise new concepts, as well as taking his time when learning a new skill. Commenting on how tech-savvy firms that can accelerate their digital transformation would have a better chance of surviving the Covid-19 pandemic unscathed, Hau Koh Foo, Director of SMU Institute of Innovation and Entrepreneurship said he has noticed how young people are often the first to transition to digital. "I think what matters more is the ability to react fast. To be able to look at all the data that's coming and chart a path," said Mr Hau. One such firm with young leaders is UglyGood – co-founded by SMU alumni Clewyn Puah (Bachelor of Accountancy) and Jeremy Lee (Bachelor of Science in Information Systems) – which was in the business of recycling fruit waste. The company jumped in to fill the demand for hand sanitisers in February, when Singapore saw a shortage of the disinfectant. 🔗 https://bit.ly/2M4PRAD

Google Singapore

How did an SMU School of Information Systems student end up getting headhunted by Google?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It all started with a heart to help. Back in 2015, Vincent Tatan—one of @smu.sis’s pioneer batch of analytics graduates—had begun noticing many of his peers and juniors struggling with analytics. Inspired, he built an analytics application to help them learn, recorded Youtube training videos, and wrote insights articles on Towards Data Science—a free online platform for idea sharing. It was these articles which eventually drove traffic to Vincent’s LinkedIn page with readers reaching out to him for advice on data analytics, and made him the top recommended candidate for hiring companies, including Google.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
“I really love to see growth in my juniors. I love learning and educating other people. And most of all, I love to give dreams to my juniors.”
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Read more about Vincent’s journey and his tips for aspiring data analysts on the #SMUBlog by clicking on the link in our @sgsmu bio or visiting https://bit.ly/smublog-vincenttatan ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

While completing a minimum of 80 hours of community service may be part of SMU’s requirement for all its undergraduates, it is always heartening to see how students take on such projects with pride and come away with fulfilling experiences.

SMU Business student Nicole Tay and @smu.sis students Masturah Binte Sulaiman and Park Ju Hee who have been volunteering at the Harvest Care Centre, have put together 3 important tips for future first-time volunteers:
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
1. Choose the programme which you are most interested in or passionate about.
2. Always keep an open mind and be ready to help.
3. Finally, volunteering might, at first, seem daunting or even intimidating.

Here's a #throwback to Hackathon@SG 2015 where our SIS alumnus Clarence Ngoh, Jeremy Ong and Eustace Zheng explored the concept of #ContactTracing. The trio created a solution called Epicenter to accelerate the process of contact tracing with the aim to help contain an epidemic at its source and prevent its spread in the community. Using WiFi signals broadcasted by mobile devices, Epicenter is able to simulate the spread of viruses like SARS and MERS based on the specific characteristics of the disease, and suggest a list of probable suspects to contact and trace. 
You can learn more from their Pitch Deck: https://www.slideshare.net/clarencenpy/epicenter-pitch-deck 
#smusis #SgSMUAlumni #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

”I signed up for a short term internship during the winter break in my penultimate year. I went in with zero expectation of getting a tech internship but miraculously I did and was posted to @landedvibe as a software engineering intern. This is by far, the most exciting internship I've taken. For that one month, I was tasked to design and implement a web calendar application to display the company's events. It was one serious rollercoaster ride. From learning new language and framework to implementation; it was learning on steroids. Fortunately, with hard work and determination, the final product was delivered on time. This would not have been possible without the help of my fellow intern @gilesccs. It has been a month of back breaking programming and continuous waves of jam packed Vietnamese culture. I felt fortunate to be able to take on one last software engineering internship before I graduate.” – Hong Yang, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2016 Intake 🔗 Undergraduate admissions are open! With Industry 4.0, digital technology is beginning to permeate extensively into every aspect of business activities, and this phenomenon gives rise to a growing industry need to understand new technologies and their implications alongside legal and regulatory issues. As a tech hub that pushes for pro-start-up and smart nation initiatives as well as a legal hub with various international firms based here, Singapore also regularly presents the key challenge of anticipating and navigating potential legal, ethical and governance issues amidst technological progress. SMU’s new Computing and Law programme equips students with a crucial interdisciplinary mode of thinking that offers graduates the opportunity to be the bridge between the tech and law realms in their future organisations. 📰 Read the full article: https://bit.ly/38sbXFZ

Things are looking up at SIS! The MOE-mandated Graduate Employment Survey was concluded recently, and we are pleased to share that Information Systems graduates earned the highest salary with a mean monthly salary of $4,549, a 9 per cent increase over the 2018 cohort ($4,160)! 👏

“During the winter break of 2019-20, I went for an overseas internship with the IT team at Unit Assessment Center Indonesia PT Telkom Indonesia (Persero) Tbk. at Bandung, Indonesia, through AIESEC's Global Entrepreneur programme. I am very grateful to have been given this opportunity to experience Indonesia, its culture and its people personally. As I had embarked on this experience alone and being an introvert by nature, I often had to step out of my comfort zone and take the initiative to interact with the locals in a language that I am not familiar with. It was not easy but I did not regret any of my decisions. I faced each challenge bravely and ended these six weeks with no regrets. Hence, not only did I made lots of new friends and new networks, I've also learnt a lot of valuable lessons.” – Luo Wan Ting, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake
_ 📽 You can watch a clip of Wan Ting recounting her internship experience here: https://bit.ly/38LPPqR
_

💘 Spread the love this Valentine’s Day! SIS Assistant Professor Tan Hwee Xian shared with us her thoughts on teaching and collaborating with her valentines – the SIS Students. “As SMU classes are small in size (we have a maximum of 45 students per class), there is a lot of class interaction, which helps to make lessons more interesting (for both myself and the students). We also get the chance to know each other better. 
Among the different types of interactions with students, I enjoy mentoring them across longer-term projects (such as internships, research-based projects or final year projects) the most. In such projects, you get to play a part in the student’s progress as they move from ideation to design, and finally implementation.” _ 📢 Undergraduate admissions are now open! Apply now for SIS at smu.sg/apply-sis

_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #Programming #Computing #Studentlife #University

To learn more, visit http://bit.ly/2RXP8Uc

“Recently, Google provided me with the opportunity to meet Developer Student Club (DSC) leads from all over Southeast Asia where we discussed on the past achievements and the possibilities for us to impact the community. In partnership with SMU. Hack, a special interest group comprising technology enthusiasts committed to spreading the passion for technology, we aim to implement Google technologies (e.g. Google Cloud, Firebase and TensorFlow) to projects that address social issues in Singapore. We conduct weekly workshops on Google technologies to arm SMU students with the capabilities of developing products to solve challenges faced by our society. 
All in all, it is a pleasure to lead SMU .Hack and SMU DSC where like-minded students gather with the intention of creating a better community through technology. We are always open to collaborate and work on projects to benefit the community, so feel free to look for me in school if anyone has any projects in mind!” – Nicolas Marc Wee Yaozong, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2018 Intake 
Do follow us on:
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/smuhack
Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/smu.hack/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/SMU.HACK
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #Studentlife #Undergrad #UniversityLife

Keen to unleash your creative energies to build cool tech but you do not have the prior programming experience? Fret not. In fact, we welcome students with little or no coding skills. 🙂 
We were pleased to be able to create engaging learning experience with visiting students from National Junior College. In the workshop, participants were introduced to the essentials for building technology in a fun and easy-to-learn way with Microsoft MakeCode. 
_

In conjunction with the SMU-Global Young Scientists Summit (GYSS), we were privileged to be invited to an exclusive dialogue with renowned computing expert and Turing Award winner Dr Leslie Lamport where he shared with us the importance of mathematics in expressing programs in a precise manner, contributing to the effectiveness of formal methods in a branch of computer science known as distributed computing.
_

It’s almost the start of the new academic year, hope everyone is getting back into the swing of things! 🙌 
Just before 2019 drew to a close, a group of SIS students organised ExploreSIS (@smu.exploresis) - a 1-day camp specially designed for Junior College and Polytechnic students to experience the vibrant campus life and learning pedagogy at SIS. Besides acquiring a little coding language under their belt, participants had the chance to engage with professors, alumni and current students, as well as learn about the current trends in technology and industry.
_

“At a macro level, [our inclusiveness] is satisfactory. We are doing much better than many other countries. However, we need to zoom into the micro-level...Stereotyping exists, and that leads to self-exclusion.” - Nazhath Faheema, @smu.sis alumna and founder of activist movement, hash.peace
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
With her activist movement, @hashpeace_, @nazhath_faheema is on a mission to tackle prejudice and extremism in Singapore, one conversation at a time. Read more about her work at the #smublog: http://bit.ly/smublog-faheemaig
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

It was a nice wrap-up for the inaugural batch of students from the Smart-City Management & Technology (SMT) major who were part of the ‘Analytics Application for Smart Living’ course. Early last month, a total of 9 teams presented their smart living solution designs and prototypes – of which 3 teams proposed evidence-based solutions for convenient grocery or meal delivery services in urban context, another 3 teams provided analytical models to bring business values to merchants, and 3 other teams pitched their ideas to community-providers. •
•
•

description:
When a bug hits, debugging large code bases can seem like finding a needle in a haystack. But fret not, the doctor's in! SIS Associate Professor David Lo shares how his research aims to solve this with automated solutions that help developers pinpoint and fix defects in their code. 📰 Read the full article: https://smu.sg/software-big-doctor 
#ComputingAtSMU #SMUResearch #SMUInsights #InformationSystems #ComputerScience #Technology

Nothing beats hands-on learning. That's why we're excited to announce a new partnership between TIBCO Software Singapore and SMU School of Information Systems. Through this partnership, our Bachelor of Science (Information Systems) students on the Digital Business Solutioning track can look forward to honing their analytics skills through selected TIBCO capabilities. 📰 Read the full article: https://smu.sg/tibco-smu-partnership

In the midst of the buzz and hype around LawTech, it is apt for us to explore the impact of new and emerging technologies on the legal sector. On 20 November, our BSc (Computing and Law) programme director Lim How Khang conducted a coding workshop on data analysis on court cases/statutes to a group of students from the Nanyang Junior College, acquainting them with basic knowledge behind data analytics.
_

“It is essential to have talented individuals from different backgrounds coming forward and working towards a great cause.” Andre Ng | Associate Cybersecurity Specialist, Cybersecurity Group⁣
⁣
As a cybersecurity specialist, Andre works closely with system owners to ensure that their systems are secure and to help them with remediation efforts when a vulnerability is found. He also organises the annual Government Bug Bounty Programme, which involves engaging various teams of engineers, system owners and the cybersecurity community to discover vulnerabilities in local government systems.⁣
⁣
Surrounded by like-minded individuals who want to make a difference, Andre believes that open communication and understanding the needs of stakeholders are key to making the collaboration work. ⁣
⁣
Aside from the colleagues that he works with, here’s something others may not know about Andre:⁣
⁣
Tell me one thing people don’t know about you. ⁣
I only wear blue shirts to work, so that I have less decisions to make in the morning. ⁣
⁣
#GovTechSG #PeopleofGovTech

Beyond urban planning and geography, Geographic Information Systems (GIS) has been widely applied across various industries to draw insights about trends, patterns and relationships - helping users make smarter decisions. •
•
•
At the GIS townhall presentation held on 18 November, students discussed the relevance of research in spatial databases, with a focus on facility planning, demographic profiling and spatial optimisation to solve the current challenges faced in many urban settings in Singapore (e.g. Tampines and Punggol) and Taiwan (e.g. Taoyuan and Tainan).
•
•
• 📸 Photo Credit: Soh Ze Yu

The digital transformation of the law practice in Singapore is gathering momentum. In this interactive workshop organised by the Bachelor of Science (Computing and Law) programme, participants had an open discussion of what it means to transform the legal industry – what are the requirements in terms of skillsets, infrastructure, information etc.? And what does that mean for young people entering the workforce? We hope that you found the workshop informative and worthwhile. •
•
•
🏆Congrats to Tai Wei Sin from Singapore Polytechnic, for walking away with a complimentary copy of the book titled ‘Tomorrow’s Lawyers: An Introduction to Your Future’, written by Richard Susskind.

_

As part of the Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) Global Internship Award program, SIS undergraduate Sze Shao Tang had an enriching maritime experience in Singapore and abroad.
•
•
• “My role as a Research and Strategy intern at Eastpoint Maritime entails digitalising and automating research and operations processes. Some of these initiatives include creating an automated regression models for freight rate forecasting and dynamically generating Key Performance Indicators data for presentations to clients. Furthermore, I had the chance to do a 4-week attachment in the Dubai office, where I experienced first-hand how shipbroking operations are done, had the chance to interact with colleagues from many different countries, and immersed in the Arabic culture of Dubai.” – Sze Shao Tang, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake

_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Smartechcular #SMUInternships

As a Blockchain Developer at IBM, each day presents an exciting new challenge to SIS Alumnus Jaren Lim, from crafting the architecture of blockchain systems, programming smart contracts, to facilitating the needs of both back-end services and front-end clients.

Q: How has SIS experience contributed to your career development? 
A: The SIS pedagogy marries technical expertise with business acumen and social skills. In particular, SMU-X courses where we worked with real-world clients gave me the avenue to apply classroom lessons in a very tangible way. Internships were also an excellent opportunity to learn on the job, understanding the needs in the industry. Altogether, these experiences have allowed me to grow professionally and pursue a career of my choice. •
•
Q: What advice would you give to prospective students?
A: Focus on the learning and how to learn. "Results are a by-product of your commitment and passion” - This was the advice given to me by Professor Steven Miller, the Founding Dean of SIS, during the SIS welcome reception. It challenged my perspective on academic grades and has served me well throughout my SIS journey. Many times, we find ourselves caught in a rat-race, seeking to compare our standing to others. ‘Learning-to-learn’ is an immensely powerful objective to hold, and this inspired me to devise my own success indicators in intellectual, social and personal spheres. 
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

"Spent my summer at Harvard University understanding how emerging tech has been shaping U.S. foreign policy towards Russia and China, right in the midst of the trade war. The battle over 5G and the emergence of deepfakes are just some of the latest tech that have big implications for U.S. foreign policy.

I'm glad to have worked with fellow Singaporean policymakers and friends from all over the world, coming together to learn about the U.S. political landscape and to formulate tech policy recommendations.

While political science is a first for me, I’ve no regrets taking it up as it broadened my perspectives of public policy in the digital age." – Goi Jia Jian, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2018 Intake (pictured second from the right)
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems

“Students from the Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology (SMT) programme were in for an exciting trip this recess week. We had the privilege to experience the future in motion with innovative gadgets showcased at the SAP Leonardo Center, which is building on SAP’s existing innovation footprint to leverage Internet-of-Things, Big Data Analytics, Machine Learning and Blockchain, to drive innovation in the Asia Pacific region. •
•
•
Interns from the SAP STAR (Student Training and Rotation) program demonstrated a few of their prototypes such as the drone which was manoeuvred by the friendly host. What really sparked my interest was the machine learning technology used to detect the clothes runway models wear during a fashion show. Just by scanning the model with the app on the camera, you can be linked directly to a web page with the clothing piece you just saw physically. To make the technology socially-inclusive, the intern demonstrated on a model with short stature (or what is known as achondroplasia). SAP hopes to deploy this technology once its full potential is unlocked. The visit ended with a debrief on SAP STAR program, highlighting the three areas of their business operation namely Sales, Presales and Innovation, Digital and Industry Value Engineering.” – Erika Aldisa Gunawan, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2018 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology
location: SAP Leonardo Center Singapore

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology

description:
“Students from the Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology (SMT) programme were in for an exciting trip this recess week. We had the privilege to experience the future in motion with innovative gadgets showcased at the SAP Leonardo Center, which is building on SAP’s existing innovation footprint to leverage Internet-of-Things, Big Data Analytics, Machine Learning and Blockchain, to drive innovation in the Asia Pacific region. •
•
•
Interns from the SAP STAR (Student Training and Rotation) program demonstrated a few of their prototypes such as the drone which was manoeuvred by the friendly host. What really sparked my interest was the machine learning technology used to detect the clothes runway models wear during a fashion show. Just by scanning the model with the app on the camera, you can be linked directly to a web page with the clothing piece you just saw physically. To make the technology socially-inclusive, the intern demonstrated on a model with short stature (or what is known as achondroplasia). SAP hopes to deploy this technology once its full potential is unlocked. The visit ended with a debrief on SAP STAR program, highlighting the three areas of their business operation namely Sales, Presales and Innovation, Digital and Industry Value Engineering.” – Erika Aldisa Gunawan, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2018 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology
location: SAP Leonardo Center Singapore

description:
Congrats to Timofey, Ambrose Tan, Wayne Loh and Shao Tang for emerging second place at the codeBOSS challenge. •
•
•
💬 "codeBOSS hosted by the Bank of Singapore (@bankofsg) provided us with a holistic hackathon experience, with questions ranging from algorithms, data science, and application development. While there was a mere 5 hour time limit, we were able to surpass our previous limitations and achieve groundbreaking levels of productivity within a short span of time. It was truly an interesting competition that pushes you beyond your comfort zone." ~ Wayne Loh Qiao Zhang, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake
_ 
#bankofsingapore #codeboss2019 #hackertrail #ComputingAtSMU

We are happy to share our students have performed exceptionally well at the CodeBoss hackathon organised by the Bank of Singapore (@bankofsg). The top prize of $2,000 went to TeamCodyFTW, comprising of Wei Xiang, Qi Xun and Patrick. •
•
•
💬 "CodeBoss was a unique experience as the challenges were structured to cover three main areas in a short amount of time: algorithms, data analytics and web application development. It tested our ability to split the tasks efficiently to leverage on our team's strengths. The data analytics section in particular featured the cleaning of messy consumer data and the creation of a regression prediction modelling pipeline which are tasks found in real world applications. Props to Bank of Singapore for the great effort to organise such an event! Glad to see that all the other SMU teams were all placed in the top 5!" ~ Yeo Qi Xun, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2016 Intake
_ 
#bankofsingapore #codeboss2019 #hackertrail #ComputingAtSMU

description:
Congratulations to our SIS students Ker Wei Xiang, Patrick Lim and Darren Lim, for clinching second place at the 2019 CodeIT Suisse!
_ 
Wei Xiang represented the team to share their thoughts about the hackathon: “The CodeIT Suisse really opened our eyes to the world of competitive programming. It tested participants based on their ability to solve challenging computational problems efficiently and rapidly. In most institutions, we are taught to be relentless problem solvers but rarely do we deal with challenging logical problems. This competition allowed us to step out of our comfort zone and dive deep into the realm of algorithms and data structures, providing us an opportunity to apply what we have learnt in the ‘Computational Thinking’ course.”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

“As an intern at Bosch, I was given the opportunity to work on a project that focuses on increasing the coverage of Bosch products throughout Asia Pacific. The building of a web automation tool to retrieve information from the web helps product specialists gain a better understanding of the market as well as identify the gaps in the market. This project was well received and met with many positive responses at a conference that was held back in August where the team I was in emerged victorious in a best-practice competition! ” – Ong Jun Xiang, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2018 Intake (pictured in the middle)
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #Internship

Meet Kar Way, our Programme Director for Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology (SMT) Major. She has recently returned from the IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE), held in Vancouver.
•
•
•
Things don’t always work out as expected, Kar Way experienced a little hiccup during the trip for missing her connecting flight at the San Francisco International Airport, which resulted in increased travel time. In the realm of technology, smart automation would have been a relief to some of these process hiccups. At the conference, Kar Way presented how automation solutions can be applied to address growing challenge in surgery scheduling and bed management that confronted most public hospitals. One of the presented papers titled ‘Data Driven Surgical Duration Prediction Model for Surgery Scheduling: a case study for practice-feasible model in a public hospital’ was selected as one of the ‘Best Healthcare Paper Award’ finalists. Congratulations!
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement

“What was deeply heartening was the immense support we received from fellow SIS students, many of whom later shared that they had been waiting for an opportunity like this. We are so grateful for every individual who helped to make Project HeartCode what it is today.” – Zul Yang
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Started by recent BSc (Information Systems) graduates Zul (@zul.yang) and Manfred Loh (@abundanceofmanny), @smuheartcode is a community service project under @smuellipsis which helps to introduce underprivileged youths to various programming languages. Kudos to our @SMU.SIS students and alumni for making the effort to leverage our technology knowledge to empower others and give back to society! Find out more about how Manny and Zul got this all started at http://bit.ly/smublog-projheartcode
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

Congrats to our students (from left to right) Amos Lam Guolun, Liu Zuo Lin, Truong Hai Bang and Wan Ding Yang for clinching the Best Application Award at the 2019 Citi Singapore Hackathon!🎉 Ding Yang represented the team to share their thoughts about the hackathon: 💬 “Over the last weekend, our task was to develop a web application consisting of four components, an authenticator, event-handler, communicator and a reporter, to provide social services a platform to recruit and manage events more efficiently and hassle-free as the volume increases.

We strongly believe that Singapore needs more than just financial resources to advance towards a greater gracious society; expertise, networks and opportunities are vital as well. Collaboration between various sectors is definitely essential for impactful interventions. Hence, we designed an integrated data-driven platform with multiple functionalities such as an automated-sharing function from various services to empower and enable all social services (e.g. dog shelter cleaning) to enhance their processes such as manpower deployment, resource allocation and better event and outreach programme management to gather feedback and continuously improve, and evolve.” _ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

"As a Digital Solutions Intern at DNV GL, I took charge of the 3D aspect of their digital twin initiative, where I developed and designed realistic and interactive industrial simulations for lifts, cranes and vessels, and integrated them into web applications. These simulations will retrieve and display streaming data from sensors (e.g. light, current, vibration) via color-coding, text, or real-time positional data (e.g. lift position). Ultimately, my working experience at DNV GL was largely insightful due to the diverse cultures and nationalities of the digital development team. It had also allowed me to gain deeper insight into the realm of emerging tech, especially in terms of digital twin technology." – Wayne Loh Qiao Zhang, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake 
_

“Internship at the Singapore Land Authority's data and geospatial services division was truly an eye-opening experience for me. Working on a data harmonisation project enabled me to better understand the intricacies and challenges of managing spatial data. I was able to further develop my technical skills and practical knowledge, particularly in data management, and gain insights into industry best practices. Furthermore, I had the chance to work on various enterprise systems for data management, visualisation, and value-driven analytics to eventually enable and empower non-technical staff to conduct self-service analytics for business reporting. 
All in all, I am grateful for this internship experience and the opportunity to work with welcoming colleagues that were more than willing to help me along the way.😀 ” – Wong Xiao Rong, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #Internship

In business, finding ways to improve and innovate is critical to success. In this highly interactive workshop on 'Business Process Modeling' conducted by SIS Senior Lecturer Rafael J. Barros, participants were provided with a step-by-step approach to analyse a business process and draw a workflow model.

Learning goes beyond the classrooms for both students as well as educators. As part of the Excellence in Education and Teaching Convention held on 11 September, our SIS Deputy Dean Venky Shankararaman was invited to helm one of the sessions, to share about his pedagogical approach of the ‘Flipped Classroom’. It was an enriching afternoon where lecturers from Singapore Polytechnic come together to recharge, and Prof Venky certainly has no shortage of knowledge to share a tip or two about the development in learning and training.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #ComputerScience

GPS (Global Positioning System) units can be a gold mine of user data for city planners and transport companies. However, while data is plentiful, there can be challenges in getting the most valuable insights. SIS Associate Professor Zheng Baihua shares how she developed a method to streamline information collection and even predict user behaviour. 
Visit https://smu.sg/connecting-dots-urban-mobility-data to learn more.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #SMUResearch #SMUInsights

“My internship with GovTech (@govtechsg) has been a rewarding one, with plenty of learning opportunities presented to me within a short span of 3 months. Over at Clusters & Technology Management Office (CTMO), I was assigned to work primarily on the Standardised DevOps Pipeline Project, with the main objective to augment the DevOps team in ramping up GovTech Services Group's Standardised CI/CD (Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment) and DevOps programme. •
•
•
What I find reassuring is to see that our curriculum is relevant, and the key concepts taught in school are actually being applied in the real world. Technical terminologies and concepts that were often presented in one of our Information Systems core modules, Enterprise Solution Management, is relatable and applied on a daily basis.” – Shawn Lee Min Hwee, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2017 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #internship

On 4 September, our BSc (Computer Science) Programme Director Hady was invited by Dunman High School, to run a workshop on “Supervised Learning via Linear and Logistic Regressions”. Students were provided with a beginner’s guide to various types of learning paradigms, and had a hands-on introduction to scikit-learn (a software machine learning library for the Python programming language). •
•
•
Once again, thanks for having us, and we hope the workshop incites a passion for computer science in younger generations!
_

“My summer internship with Smart Nation and Digital Government (SNDGO) was magnificent! The working experience enabled me to gain a better perspective of how Singapore develops as a leading smart city. 
As an intern, I had the opportunity to attend the Smart Nation Innovation Week, where I conducted strategic analysis and international bench-marking of designated countries. I also embarked on an international ranking project which provided an assessment of Singapore's global standing as a smart city and digital government, as well as how SNDGO should prioritise its international engagements.” – Clint Ho Wei Jie, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2018 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #Internship

In this tech-dominated world, no one should be denied a chance to master tech-savviness. With the desire to help youths level up in the digital era, SIS alumni Zul Yang Guo Qiang and Manfred Loh Pei En decided to kickstart SMU Project HeartCode, an initiative which helps to introduce underprivileged youths to various programming languages.
•
•
•
Visit https://bit.ly/2lHxcAQ to find out how our alumni and undergraduates are helping youths with their carefully curated web development courses. 
_

• • • • • •
Being in completely different faculties in SMU didn't stop them from finding each other through their love for K-pop. Meet Vera Sun (@SgSMUSOL undergrad), Janessa Sim (SMU.Accountancy undergrad), Moh Moh San (@SMU.SIS undergrad), the co-founders of @KpopKart—the first ever K-pop marketplace for fans all around the world to buy and sell K-pop merchandise.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Starting a business from a mere interest may seem frivolous to some but this is far from the truth for the trio: "Targeting the niche market of K-pop was not a popular move to make. In fact, we received numerous sceptical comments about the scalability of the idea. However, with growing statistics of the K-pop market as well as increasing consumer demand for niche/personalised products, we believed in the huge potential of growth for KpopKart." – Janessa
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Don't let setbacks and criticisms stop you from pursuing a potentially great idea. Take it from our three SMUggers here—with the right attitude and approach, you might find just the right formula. #Hwaiting!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Read more about KpopKart's story on the #SMUBlog: http://bit.ly/kpopkart-ig

•
SIS Professor Lim Ee Peng shares how he is using social analytics to study and match users across multiple social networks and why these insights can help the government and companies reach their audiences with more tailored recommendations.

“Over the summer I had the opportunity to intern at SAS Institute, a multinational developer of analytics software. As an undergraduate pursuing a second major in Analytics, it was an eye opening experience as I got to witness first-hand the power that understanding data can bring to the table, as well as its limitless application throughout industries. From watching the team at SAS Institute continuously strive to help businesses harness the benefits of Analytics, I learnt that we are constrained only by our imagination - because you never know until you try. •
•
•
Being surrounded by many like-minded colleagues that were passionate about Data Science, they were more than happy to share their experiences in the field, providing me with resources and valuable advice on where I should go from here. This valuable opportunity has certainly opened up so many doors for me, and I look forward to what’s to come!” – Lim Pei Xuan, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2016 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #Internship

Team Tortoise Honey, comprising of SIS Year 3 students Bryan Tan Wei Yoong, Dionysus Yan Hong Chen, Loh Yu Jin, and Michelle Firstania Lion, has clinched the first prize in the UBS Group Chief Operation Office (GCOO) Case Challenge 2019! 🥇🎉
•
•
•
The team was challenged to re-engineer the remittance process of a fictitious bank to improve its efficiency. Putting their classroom knowledge to good use, their proposed solution included a web portal where the client can request for remittance payment and submit relevant documents. It also included an integrated ticketing system which enables an employee to pass each transaction downstream - from form submission to sum disbursement. •
•
•
For the full article, visit https://smu.sg/ubs-gcoo-case-challenge-2019
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

A group of 10 students from the SIS Ace Programme has recently participated in an experiential learning trip to Hangzhou and Shanghai, from 11 to 18 August. Other than attending guided tours conducted by local topic experts, the students had the opportunity to examine the intersection of China's rich culture and modern reinvention.
•
•
•
Check out the full article written by SIS Year 3 Student Foo Chi Jao at https://smu.sg/sis-ace-hangzhou-shanghai
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Learning how to tackle fake news and analyse the potential legal and technological tools to battle such trend of falsehood was the focus of the ‘Perils of Fake News’ workshop, an initiative by the Bachelor of Science (Computing & Law) programme, co-organised by the SMU School of Information Systems and SMU School of Law (@sgsmusol). •
•
• 
Following a keynote speech by technology lawyer Zaid Hamzah, students were divided into small groups to brainstorm “credible” fabricated news and think of the legal and technological ways in which they can be squashed in. •
•
•
The workshop was attended by participants from various polytechnics and junior colleges. We would like to congratulate the winning team comprising of Jethro Cheung from Singapore Polytechnic, and Isabella Maya Quah and Hamzah Abudul Rashid from Victoria Junior College! (Swipe to the second picture)
•
•
•
To learn more about our new Bachelor of Science (Computing & Law) programme, visit www.sis.smu.edu.sg/bsc-computing-law 
_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #ComputingandLaw
