“Solace (@solacedotcom) is in the business of moving data, and as a pre-sales intern, my main tasks revolved around creating demos that utilise and showcase the abilities of Solace's advanced events brokers. A usual day for me apart from coding and designing demos, includes brainstorming new demo iterations with my supervisor and collecting feedback from the team. This is my first internship in a more technical role and it took me a while to figure out the core technology and learn the programming languages used. I would say the culture at SIS has also instilled in me the importance of ‘learning-to-learn’ - that is to be proactive to explore new technologies. This mindset especially, proved valuable in helping me to successfully complete my internship with Solace.” – Rajiv Abraham Xavier, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake
_

It’s a fresh start to the academic year, and let’s hear what some of the new faces at SIS have to share about their aspirations: •
•
• 💬 “I strongly believe that Information Systems is an area of study that gives me a greater potential to excel in the future. The salary prospects of SIS undergraduate degree is a plus point for me too!” – Sun Yuyang, SIS Year 1 Student, 2019 Intake (pictured on the left)
•
•
•
💬 “For me, I was drawn to the rigorous course structure and broad-based curriculum for Bachelor of Science in Information Systems. I hope the grounding in the theories and applications will push me to my greatest ability to become the best. (I’m targeting to achieve GPA 4.0 in my course of study! Till then...☺️)” – Sri Khaliesah Asri. SIS Year 1 Student, 2019 Intake (pictured in the centre)
•
•
•
💬 “I chose to study at SIS because I want to venture into a course that explores a wider scope of IT with an element of business. With this combination, I believe I’ll be better prepared and equipped with the skills needed in the workforce. Other than that, I feel that the good salary prospects upon graduation plays a part in my choice too.” - Nur Shaziera Binte Ismail, SIS Year 1 Student, 2019 Intake (pictured on the right)
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

“Internship with J.P. Morgan has allowed me to gain valuable insights into how technology is driven by one of the world’s largest financial services institution.
•
•
• 
One of the key takeaways I had as an intern was learning how technology plays an important role in the firm’s strategy. I had the opportunity to work and interact with technology professionals and senior leaders to understand how the different lines of business generate revenue for the firm. •
•
•
I also took part in J.P. Morgan’s Global Technology Innovation week with my fellow interns and had a first-hand experience of how ideas and innovations were generated across the firm. It has been a privilege to work in such a cultivating and innovative environment. Ending my stint will definitely feel bittersweet, but it gets me industry-ready. The internship has definitely honed both my hard and soft skills!” – Joel Tay Da Yuan, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2016 Intake
_

description:
As a Data Science Intern at JTC (@jtc_sg), Lionel was given the opportunity to work with the Digital Infrastructure team to build and maintain data pipelines, design application programming interface (APIs) to be utilised by the business users, as well as perform descriptive statistics and analysis to develop new insights for business’ needs. Let’s hear more of what he has to share about the internship.
•
•
•
💬 “As a major player in the real estate industry, JTC has given me the opportunity to understand the problems specific to the industry as well as the considerations in estate development in Singapore. With the vast amount of data available, I was exposed to real analytics problem in the industry and had the opportunity to put what I have learnt in SMU into practice to assist in the analytics project at JTC.
•
•
•
The internship experience was also a unique one as we got to visit some of JTC’s developments such as the Jurong Innovation District (JID) and Seletar Aerospace Park (SAP). During our trip to JID, we had meaningful conversations with employees of the various Advanced Manufacturing companies in the district that uses the Industrial Internet of Things in their manufacturing processes. We were also challenged by the HR team to brainstorm new technological ideas to enhance the living and working spaces in JTC – we worked in teams with interns from other departments and exchanged various ideas unique to our domain.
•
•
•
Overall, I had a lot of fun in JTC and my advice to all those who are embarking on their first internship is to go in with an open heart, learn as much as you can and don’t be afraid to speak to people across different domains. Something that was impressionable to me during my time at JTC was the initiative by my team to talk to different departments, which gave us a deeper understanding of the business processes in JTC and allowed us to form many meaningful connections in the company.” – Lionel Ng Ze Ji, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Information Systems Student, 2017 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #ComputerScience #Internship

📢 A shoutout to our SIS Alumnus Wong Wai Tuck and his team-mates for reigning the top spot at this year’s DefCon security conference, widely considered the “World Cup” of hacking! 🎉
•
•
• 💬 “Security has been my passion ever since I was young. However, it was only in university that I really started to take this seriously. I had the opportunity to do so under the SMU- Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) Fast Track Masters programme. In my undergraduate days, I led the security club, SMU Whitehat Society. We organised a ton of fun competitions, namely WhiteHacks, which I am still proud of today. Later, when I moved to the US for my Masters in CMU; I was really lucky and got to play with the top security team, the Plaid Parliament of Pwning (PPP), at DefCon's 'World Series of Hacking'. The 72-hour contest follows a Capture the Flag (CTF) format, in which teams earn points by breaking into other teams’ servers to collect virtual "flags", while simultaneously defending their own systems from other teams’ attacks. All in all, It was a grueling and challenging competition and I think I slept for a total of 8 hours for the 3 days! In the end, my teammates and I came out top in the competition. I couldn't have done it without my amazing team-mates. I have a ton of things to learn from them - and am eternally grateful for the opportunity to study in the US.” – SIS Alumnus Wong Wai Tuck, Graduating Class of 2019
_

#ComputingAtSMU #InformationSystems #SchoolofInformationSystems #Technology

🔍 Did you know that SMU students are amongst the group of 10 students to have the opportunity to learn about the latest ICT developments and acquire industry experience through the Seeds for the Future programme. This is made possible in the partnership between Huawei (@huawei) and Infocomm Media Development Authority (@imdasg). We are glad to have our SIS Student Hui Chiann on board to share her thoughts about the 2 weeks trip. •
•
•
💬 “This summer, I was provided with the opportunity to visit Huawei’s headquarters in Shenzhen where I gained knowledge on the latest technologies in the industry (5G, cloud computing, AI etc) and exchanged views with like-minded students from other countries (Bahrain, Iraq and Cambodia). Through the intensive lessons, I had the chance to experience the workings of 5G technology firsthand and ultimately configured my own 5G base station. With 5G being rolled out in Singapore next year, this trip has definitely provided me with a head start!”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #ComputerScience

“Interning in JTC (@jtc_sg) has been fulfilling in a variety of ways. I’ve the opportunity to embark on an end-to-end analytics project which puts my technical skills into practice and stretches me to think outside the box. My biggest takeaway is the significance of communication with different stakeholders in a data analytics project to share data insights and understand the requirements of end users. I’m also very grateful to be able to work with friendly colleagues and mentors who guided me well and gave me the confidence to overcome any challenges. 
Above all, it was a unique opportunity to broaden my horizon in industrial development through intern site visits and learning journeys. I’m truly thankful to be part of this enriching internship programme which allows me to forge friendships and gain deeper insights in urban development.” – Bak Ing Sin, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems): Smart-City Management & Technology Student, 2017 Intake
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Internship

The annual Code:XtremeApps: (CXA) hackathon concluded on 30 July with the prize presentation ceremony awarding the best solutions that addressed several real-world challenge statements posed. •
•
•
We are delighted to share that Team SDK comprises of First Year SIS Student Shazli, and his peers Dominic and Ken from the Singapore University of Technology and Design, walked away with the 🥈second prize! •
•
•
💬 On what sets them apart from their competitors, Shazli enthused, “I realised my mind takes on a more business-centric approach to tackling the challenge statements presented. I acted as the guy who did the analysis of the application to be developed and all. And a bit of the Android UI coding as well. Hence, I would say the solution we created, was really something which we can vouch to be a good minimum viable product (MVP) for use in the market out there!”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

The annual Code:XtremeApps: (CXA) hackathon concluded on 30 July with the prize presentation ceremony awarding the best solutions that addressed several real-world challenge statements posed. •
•
•
We are delighted to share that Team SDK comprises of First Year SIS Student Shazli, and his peers Dominic and Ken from the Singapore University of Technology and Design, walked away with the 🥈second prize! •
•
•
💬 On what sets them apart from their competitors, Shazli enthused, “I realised my mind takes on a more business-centric approach to tackling the challenge statements presented. I acted as the guy who did the analysis of the application to be developed and all. And a bit of the Android UI coding as well. Hence, I would say the solution we created, was really something which we can vouch to be a good minimum viable product (MVP) for use in the market out there!”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

"I had a wonderful and fulfilling student life at SMU SIS. I am very happy and thankful to be graduating and celebrating the past 4 years of hard work and achievements with my friends.

Prior to graduation, I have already started working as a Principal Solution Specialist at Microsoft. My main goal is to work closely with partners of the organisation, to drive digital transformation through the adoption of Internet-of-Things (IoT) solutions." - Sally Chin, Bachelor of Science (Information Systems) Graduate, Class of 2019
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #UniversityLife #SMUCommencement2019 #Graduation

“SMU is A Different U. I was lucky to be able to sit in one of the lectures when I was waiting for my enlistment. To my surprise, instead of traditional lecture hall, SMU uses seminar room which allow Professors to have close interaction with students. Personally, I feel having bi-directional communication makes things much more interesting as compared to omni-direction. The lectures are designed for interactive learning which encourage us to share our thoughts or doubts. 
Besides that, the bond with our "SIS family" is irreplaceable. To all incoming students, be open-minded and make time to socialise. You will find yourself within the SIS family circle in no time. The seniors and staff are always there to give you certain tips and advice on academic matters like modules planning, as well as moral support.” 😉 - Poh Boon Keat [SMU Bachelor of Science (Information Systems) Graduate, Class of 2019], with Ms Jeandie Lim from the SIS Office of the Dean
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #UniversityLife #SMUCommencement2019 #Graduation

It’s less than a month before the school term starts! We hope all of you, incoming freshmen, enjoyed the camps and holidays thus far. 🙌
•
•
•
“Why did you choose SIS?” - We posed this question to some of the SIS freshmen during the Academic Briefing session held on 24 July, and here are some of their responses:
•
•
•
💬 “I have a keen interest in technology and previously graduated with the Diploma in Business Information Technology at Singapore Polytechnic, I wish to further continue my studies in the field of IT, to expand my knowledge and skill set.” - John Chow Li Wei (pictured on the left)
•
•
•
💬 “I chose SIS because I like the school environment and the well-connected location! Besides that, I look forward to attending the seminars as the professor to student ratio is small which I believe will be conducive to my learning.” - Elgin (pictured in the centre) •
•
•
💬 “I personally like the school’s core curriculum which teaches skills that are relevant and useful in the 21st century. In addition, I plan to enter the private industry in the future, hence I feel that the marriage between IT and business will be of great help!” - Yao Ying (pictured on the right)
_

Congrats to SIS Student Liu Mengru (pictured left in the photo) and her team for emerging as the runner-up at the NUS-NUHS-MIT AI Datathon and EXPO! 🎉 •
•
•
Held for the 2nd year, this event is a focal point to showcase and discuss the application of Artificial Intelligence in clinical practice and its implications in the age of precision medicine. •
•
•
👩‍💻 Mengru who is majoring in the Smart-City Management & Technology programme, had the chance to work alongside clinicians, data scientists and peers from other institutions to build an IT solution with healthcare data support. Through this datathon, she gained an insight of the current clinical challenges, and is thankful for this valuable opportunity to be part of the cross-disciplinary collaboration, to extract vast amounts of data and knowledge available to benefit healthcare providers and ultimately, patients. 
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Healthcare

Team Black Pink, comprising of students Anita Chia and Jorden Seet from SMU School of Information Systems, and Jaylen Li from SMU School of Economics, has done us proud by coming up on top at the Singapore round of the 2019 International Quant Championship! 🎉
•
•
•
👨‍💻 The competition enabled the team to see more clearly the role that technology plays in quantitative finance. “A computer is not only able to calculate and price financial instruments much faster than human beings, it is also able to automate many manual processes, such as algorithm generation and statistical scraping. This shows the importance of being technology-savvy even as a quant,” added Jorden. •
•
•
👩‍💻 The competition also opened the eyes of the team to the various ways to derive quantitative insights in the financial markets. “Some took their inspiration from biological processes,  thermodynamics, financial events and many more. It really shows that we are not only limited by our own creativity and knowledge”, Anita enthused. 
_ 
Visit smu.sg/2019-international-quant-championship for the full article.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #StudentLife

Here’s SIS student Debbie Lee Shan Ying (@D_ebbieeeeeee) sharing her reflective piece. •
•
•
💬 “Speaking from my experience as a Public Relations Director of the SMU EllipSIS student club, and  having interacted with so many working adults and campus recruiters, I realised times have changed with the awareness and advocation of women in tech, especially in the past 5 years. Much has been written in the tech and business press about the positive change in expediting the promotion of women in tech such as proactive organisations focusing on gender parity and celebration of International Women’s Day. I would say our generation is non-conventional and more open to innovation. I believe in the future, maybe in the next 5-10 years, it will get better in terms of the gender imbalance as the next wave of leaders from our generation are the ones who will be leading this movement!”
•
•
•
📸 The picture was taken before Debbie embarked on her Technopreneurship Study Mission trip to Hong Kong and Shen Zhen in May. Do look up ‘SMUSISTSM’ on Facebook to learn more about the learning journey and get a glimpse of the entrepreneurship scene. 
www.facebook.com/SMUSISTSM/

Co-organised by the Ministry of Home Affairs (@mhasingapore) and the Singapore Cybersecurity Consortium, the Cyber Investigators' Challenge is a competition in which participants attempt to outwit the “criminals” by solving cases in a variety of real-life scenarios, across different platforms from computers to Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices and unmanned platforms. •
•
•
🏆 We'd like to say a huge congratulations to the winning pair which comprises of SIS Student Sim Cher Boon (pictured on the left in the photo), and Lee Zhen Hao from the Singapore Institute of Technology. •
•
•
💬  Here’s Cher Boon sharing his motivation for taking up the challenge: “The key driver to take part in competitions is the desire to discover more out of classroom knowledge. It is one of the best ways to prepare for the industry, as the challenges are often crafted to reflect real world scenarios.”

What is the probability of obtaining any side of rolling a die? You might intuitively know that the likelihood is 1/6. But how do we work that out? •
•
•
💬 On 16 July, Visiting Assistant of Information Systems Professor Aldy Gunawan conducted a workshop to a group of eagle-eyed students from Temasek Polytechnic, specifically from the diploma course of study in Big Data Management & Governance, and Business Intelligence & Analytics.
•
•
•
🎲 In the 3 hour workshop, students get to build a simple simulation model using some basic excel functions to visualise the possible outcomes and probability of rolling a die.
_

We are delighted to share that our SIS senior year students Toh Zi Jie (@tohzj) and Jorden Seet (@jordenhappyhope) were awarded second place at the Kaspersky Secur'IT Cup 2019 – a competition dedicated to the challenges of a rapidly changing world and tackling security issues posed by new technologies. •
•
•
💡 Their project was on Dynamic Keystroke Profiling for Identity Verification. Essentially, what their project does is to use Machine Learning to create typing profiles of people as a method of authentication. A hacker accessing your computer, for example, would be detected by the algorithm since their typing habits would be different from yours, and allow for action to be taken. •
•
•
👨‍💻 Through this competition, Zi Jie and Jorden learnt that innovative technology is not derived from blindly using AI or blockchain, but rather innovation lies in how the appropriate technology is deployed to tackle a problem from a different perspective.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #StudentLife

There is no doubt that some of the most valuable lessons and experience were picked up outside the classroom. We are pleased to share the notable wins from the SMU Caderas Latinas (@smucaderaslatinas) which won 2 awards at the India International Dance Congress, held from 4 to 7 July 2019 in Bangalore. •
•
•
🏆 Congratulations to SIS Student Bryan Khng who is also the President of the SMU Caderas Latinas, and Vu Le Hgoc Tram Emma (SMU Lee Kong Chian School of Business, Year 2), for achieving 1st Runner’s up in the Salsa [Semi-Professional Couple] category, out of a total of 10 couples. The senior team has also achieved an amazing feat by clinching the International Championship Title out of a total of 6 teams! •
•
•
🎭 To all the incoming freshmen, do follow SMU Vivace (@smuvivace) to see what SMU student life has to offer. This is the best time to gather like-minded friends for a great time at campus! 
_

Participating in competitions offer many relishing rewards for students. Besides the opportunity to hone their skillsets, students may also gain valuable insights and a chance to network with industry leaders. •
•
•
💬 SIS Student John Ng Xun Jie (pictured on the left) who is majoring in Smart-City Management & Technology programme, has recently teamed up with his seniors, to put their theoretical knowledge into practicality in the IBM Call for Code (@officialcallforcode) 2019 - a global challenge that seeks to inspire developers to create open source technology solutions to mitigate the impact of natural disasters. •
•
•
💡 They are currently at the ideation stage to pitch their ideas on early fire detection to Singapore Civil Defence Force (@myscdf). Stay tuned for more updates!

SIS Student Mengru (@316316308l) revels in programming and writing code, she added that the collaborative and socially diverse environment at SIS has propelled her in her academic pursuits: “We often face stereotypes that males tend to outperform females in many areas, but we need to acknowledge that being interested in technology or computing is not just a male quality. Digital technology in particular is now so deeply embedded in all our lives that from a consumer perspective, there really is no gender divide. Thankfully, my peers in school are supportive and display great team camaraderie. For instances, we help to counter-check for errors in our codes before submissions, and are willing to share our notes before midterms and finals. These are little gestures that mean a lot to me.”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #WomenInTech

Have you ever wondered how things in life are assigned? Why did you get into that school? Which applicant would get the job? Which patient would receive a kidney from which donor? Who would marry whom? 
All these fascinating formulations of algorithms were unraveled in ‘A Glimpse into the Sorting Hat of Life’ workshop conducted by Associate Professor Hady W. Lauw on 4 July, to a group of students specially from the Diploma in Information Security & Forensics and Diploma in Financial Informatics, Ngee Ann Polytechnic.
_

SIS Alumnus Andre Ng, an associate cybersecurity specialist at GovTech, shared what sparked off his interest in cybersecurity and what his current job entails. He credited his studies for giving him “a good blend” of technical skills in policy, strategy and management. Andre was part of the SMU-Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) Fast Track Programme, where he graduated with a degree in information systems from SMU and a master’s degree in security policy & management from CMU in the United States.

_

Visit smu.sg/smu-cmu-fast-track to find out more about the SMU-CMU Fast Track Programme.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

To all the ladies out there, if you want to know what the learning journey at SIS holds for you, there's no one better to ask than our student ambassador Amanda Wong (@omgmunchies). 😊 And if you are wondering what she is holding on to? It’s Cody the owl – our very own mascot. 🦉
_ “While I know that the technology sector is mainly dominated by males, I am not affected by the gender disparity and I have never belittle myself just because I’m a woman pursuing a degree in Information Systems. I hope that my fellow ladies out there would share the same thought - never let your gender define or limit your decision. Just be YOU.
_

Just like how digital trends are always evolving for the better, the curriculum at SIS is constantly revamped to stay relevant and align to meet the needs of the industry. It is something that I personally feel is crucial in the technology field. Besides that, more importantly than the course content taught, the school cultivates one to be a self-driven learner and I believe this ‘learning-to-learn’ attitude would serve us, regardless of gender, a competitive advantage when we start working in the corporate world.”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #WomenInTech

What impact do online hacking discussions have on cyber-attacks? You might be surprised to learn that open discussions of hacking has been shown to decrease attacks. 
Listen to the podcast at smu.sg/sharing-hacking-knowledge, as SIS Assistant Professor Wang Qiuhong shares her work on the net impact of hacking discussions on cyber-attacks and the regulation of hacker forums. 
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #WomenInTech

Learning is something that humans do naturally. Machines, on the other hand, could use some help from SIS Associate Professor Steven Hoi. 
Visit smu.sg/machines-as-students to find out more what exactly does his work with them entail?

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

The state of women in tech does present a kind of quarter-full glass perspective, but that is not holding SIS Student Bernadine Lye (@_lightupmyworld) back. 
_ “Gender imbalance in the field of technology is apparent and is also not surprising that the males outnumber the females in my cohort. However, that does not dissuade me to pursue a degree at SIS. 
Being a woman does not define your ability to code. I strongly believe that the gender gap in the tech industry should not be a deterrence for women's entry but an inspiration for a new frontier of women in tech. To be honest, as a student coming from a Science background, the tech industry is not somewhere I would have envisioned myself in. Nevertheless I took the leap and the learning journey so far has reignited my interests in computing, and has definitely advanced my skillsets in IT and business innovation. What's more, I especially love the friendly and inclusive environment where there is equal opportunity for all!” _ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #WomenInTech

Wishing all our Muslim friends a joyous celebration and enjoy the festivities ahead. Selamat Hari Raya Aidlifitri!
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

SIS alumnus Kelvin Chng founded the "Netflix of cars". Find out how he applies a subscription-based model to his start-up, Carro (@carro.sg) at https://bit.ly/2QClx1v
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Roll up your sleeves and go full throttle with Teh Ming Yi (@mingyiiiii) in our new #WomenInTech series! •
•
“These few years we have seen conversations about gender equality being pushed to the forefront which sparked positive changes across multiple industries, and this includes the tech industry. More and more tech giants are encouraging women to take part in tech innovations, and we also see more women being hired in firms to encourage diversity in the workplace. However, I think more needs to be done to narrow this gap. •
•
It was never about your gender, but your interest and how much effort you put into it. Sometimes we need to stop thinking if certain tech areas are more suited for guys or girls but focus on what you can bring to the table. I think that is more important.”
_
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #WomenInTech

Did you know entrepreneurial students who aspire to develop their innovations for commercial use can look forward to an environment that provides strong support for understanding the "go-to-market" process, intellectual property management and securing start-up funding? •
•
Aspiring students can work closely with SMU Institute of Innovation & Entrepreneurship (IIE) for all aspects of entrepreneurship support, including mentoring and guidance from experienced and successful entrepreneurs. •
•
Recently, Cudy (@cudy_sg), a Singapore-based online tuition platform started by two SIS students Alexander Lim and Sean Lam, has raised an undisclosed six-figure sum in a seed funding round from investors and attracted 500 freelance tutors to sign up since their launch in 2018!
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

SIS alumnus Alvin Poh became a millionaire after he and his partner sold their Web hosting company, Vodien Internet Solutions, for $30 million to an Australian technology firm. As a way to show his gratitude, he gave $250,000 to his alma mater SMU to start the Alvin Poh Scholarship, giving financial aid to needy undergraduates. He graduated from SMU with a bachelor’s degree in information systems and a master’s in information technology (e-business) from Carnegie Mellon University. According to him, he is grateful for the overseas experience that SMU gave him and that his education has taught him to think critically and develop problem-solving and other skills that helped him as an entrepreneur.
_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Here’s SIS sophomore student Vinnie Chu (@ballchuuu) standing against a backdrop of the bustling central business district, taking her interactions into the exuberant city life for an enriching learning encounter.
_ 
Vinnie is majoring in the Smart-City Management and Technology programme, and her interests lie in technology and its repercussions on urban planning and society. This is what she has to say about the inclusive and collaborative community at SIS: •
•
“I have been blessed with a very supportive network of friends and professors who have given me many opportunities to hone my skills and explore new technologies of my interest. These include dabbling into Internet of Things (IoT) and data analytics to build solutions such as a Smart Facilities Management System, which utilises light, humidity and temperature sensors to improve conditions and achieve energy efficiency in study areas. 
Apart from experimenting with new technologies, SMU has also given me many enriching opportunities to give back to the society. A good example is my involvement in Project Heartcode (@smuheartcode), a community service project that gave me the chance to share my knowledge and teach the underprivileged youth basic web development and IoT. •
•
I am truly glad that the school recognises the importance of diversity in this digital revolution. And here’s to a lifelong journey in tech with more experimentations and solutions created to better the lives of people!”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #WomenInTech

Blockchain technology's impact has evolved far beyond cryptocurrencies. One hot area of debate is its impact on the environment. Boon or bane? We find out more from SIS third year student and SMU Blockchain (@smublockchain) member Jorden Seet. 
_ 
Visit smu.sg/blockchain-impact to learn more.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #Blockchain

Great news for our juniors - SMU and Citi Ventures have signed an MOU to offer financial technology courses to SMU undergraduates from January next year! This marks the first time that the Citi University Partnerships in Innovation & Discovery (CUPID) programme is offered to a university in Asia. 
Visit smu.sg/smu-citi-ventures to read the press release. 
_

"However cool a technology is, it’s uncool if they can’t help to alleviate the issues faced by people," said SIS Alumna Siti Rabiatul Adawiyah Binte Hairy who is currently an Associate Software Engineer at GovTech (@govtechsg).
•
•
Siti joined GovTech in July 2017 as a fresh graduate under the Technology Associate Programme and has worked on large-scale projects such as the Business Grants Portal. •
•
Visit https://bit.ly/2WgVH8x to learn more about her experience.

SMU has always been committed to nurturing global perspectives and cross-cultural understanding among our students. Here's SIS Final Year student Malcolm Nathaniel Ng's (@malnatty) sharing of how the overseas exposure broadened his horizons. •
•
"Being a Thai Chinese with little recollection of my childhood in Chiang Rai, I chose to do my student exchange programme in Thailand. It was an opportunity to return to my cultural roots, allowing me to learn and experience what it was like to live and study there. 
_

The friends I made, from local Thai students to foreign exchange students, definitely shaped my entire exchange experience. Studying and assignments aside, we celebrated festivals and explored myriad cuisines together. Along the way, I have also picked up on some cultural nuances – how certain gestures that was universally acceptable were considered inappropriate to the Thai culture, and it also serves as a reminder to myself to keep an open mind towards different ideas. 
Most importantly, the friendships forged through deep conversations and shared experiences are invaluable; they are the memories that will stay with me.” •
•
Open more doors for your future. Common acceptance closes 24 May 2019. Accept your offer and begin your #SMUExperience today: https://smu.sg/accept-offer
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

“I chose SMU for its unique seminar-style of teaching and for the support rendered towards co-curricular activities. SMU provides students with numerous opportunities to excel and endeavour outside of academia, and I am confident that given these opportunities, I will be able to further my passion outside of the curriculum. Furthermore, the University teaches its students to be articulate and confident, beyond simply being outspoken. School holiday is a break from classes, but it is also an opportunity to get ahead. SIS sophomore Kee Cheng Heng (@keechengheng) is making the most of his summer break. He has just returned from a tech conference in Seattle, and on the following day, attended a sharing session at the Innova Junior College.
_ 
Hear what he has to share about the SIS experience thus far: “Entering SIS has been one of the best choices I've made in my life. The seniors are very welcoming and always willing to lend a helping hand, be it in studies or just giving pieces of advice. In SIS, we are given the golden opportunity to meet an array of people with the common understanding that technology is getting more and more prevalent in our daily lives. No matter which industry we go to, technology will be a constant. 
To all the prospective SIS students, come and embrace technology together with us. Be exposed to the cutting edge hardware/software and also learn how to leverage on the resources that we are fortunate enough to have access to.”
_ 
The first window of acceptance closes on 24 May 2019. Accept your offer today: http://bit.ly/2Yccx5P
_

Technology, which is changing the way we live, work and play, offers a golden opportunity to address the growing needs of silver populations around the world. 
Mobile app Homage (@homagecare) is bringing the connectivity of technology to the elderly through simple interfaces and personalised senior home care services. Started by SMU School of Information Systems alumnus Duong Tong with his two co-founders, they were driven by personal experience. 
_

Visit smu.sg/homage-harnessing-technology to read the full story.

_

Here’s SIS senior year student Sheryl Yeo (@sherylovelleyeo) taking over our Instagram.
_____ “Well some people may say that SIS Students are 🤓 geeks who are glued to our laptops all day, but that’s not true. In fact, most of us do have our share of fun and perks! 🥳 
_

Do you know that we have a common space in our campus known as the "SIS Project Way"? (Swipe to see more 📸) It is a place for us to unplug to recharge. Most of the SIS students will gather there to do projects, exchange ideas and share our knowledge with one another. You can also see moments of frustration (😡debugging in process...), stress (😥 mugging for exams) and joy (🙃 celebrating accomplishments, 🎂 birthdays, etc.). _

Besides the facilities, I also like how SIS electives give us a holistic experience in both tech and management, equipping us with the 💡 future-ready career skills. What’s more, we also have the privilege to access to a diverse range of databases at the SMU Libraries (@sgsmu.library), and opportunities to work with industry partners through SMU-X courses!” ✌🏻
_ 
The common acceptance closes 24 May 2019. Accept your offer today by clicking on the link: smu.sg/admissions2019-ig
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

With big data in the limelight, more and more firms are integrating it into consumer businesses. But big data isn't new—it's been in existence for as long as humans have made records of their work. SIS Senior Lecturer Seema Chokshi takes us through the evolution of big data to how we see it today.
_ 
Visit smu.sg/big-data-consumer to learn more.
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

It was a day of ideating and bringing digital ideas to life at the ‘Ant-Bytes Hackathon’, a yearly event held on 27 April, and hosted by our very own SMU Anthill Society –  a special interest group which aims to value-add student experiences in the field of Smart-City Management and Technology. 
_

During the themed hackathon, participants were grouped in teams to collaborate and develop Internet-of-Things driven prototypes to address urbanisation issues. Each team was provided with a Micro:bit which is a pocket-sized codable computer with built-in sensors to detect properties such as motion, light and temperature. 
_

At the end the day, each team was given a chance to pitch their ideas and demonstrate their accomplishments to the panel of industry leaders. All in all, the hackathon showed one thing above all else – a promising idea first starts with a deep understanding of the diverse needs of the end users, and thereafter synthesising IT solutions to facilitate efficiency and improve sustainability of a Smart City. 
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

SMU hosted the fourth episode of Perspectives Season 8 “Innovate first, regulate later: Can we truly build blockchains for a better world?” on 14 March 2019 which featured an esteemed panel of thought leaders including Prof Paul Griffin, Associate Professor of Information Systems (Practice) and Director, MITB (Financial Technology & Analytics) Programme. The panel discussion centred around the many opportunities for us to take advantage of the decentralised nature of blockchain to enhance social good.
_ 
Watch the mediacast at smu.sg/innovate-first
_

The finals are finally over, and everything is soon coming to fruition for SIS graduand Abdul Haqqim (@ah_ah_siol). He has been rehearsing his dance moves for months on end, and all hyped up for the dance production in May, with SMU Eurhythmix (@smuemix) - a hip-hop dance club of SMU. 
When asked about the fondest memory of studying in SIS, Abdul Haqqim specially mentioned the MetamorphoSIS Camp (@smu.metamorphosis), the Freshman Orientation Camp that gave him the headstart to his university days. He still recalled how he was worried back then about the lack of knowledge in coding. But thanks to the strong spirit of friendship forged through the camp, and the nurturing culture of peer support, he was able to keep up with his studies.
_

8 teams of students from the 'IS439 Internet of Things (IoT): Technology & Applications' course have recently concluded their Poster Day at *SCAPE (@scapesg), which is also the industry sponsor for this term. Over the course of 15 weeks, students had to come up with IoT-driven solutions to solve real challenges or problems faced by *SCAPE. These include ideas to reduce electricity wastage, manage overcrowding, drive traffic to retail space, and many more. 
_

description:
While we enjoy the convenience of food delivery and online shopping, it has taken a toll on our roads and environment. SMU Professor of Information Systems, Lau Hoong Chuin, speaks about the necessity of coordinating movement of trucks around the island and the project he’s working on to tackle this issue. 
Watch the video at https://bit.ly/2VgZlPk
_

While we enjoy the convenience of food delivery and online shopping, it has taken a toll on our roads and environment. SMU Professor of Information Systems, Lau Hoong Chuin, speaks about the necessity of coordinating movement of trucks around the island and the project he’s working on to tackle this issue. 
Watch the video at https://bit.ly/2VgZlPk

The exam week is looming but always keep a smile on your face. 😊🌻
_ 
Learning doesn’t just stop in the classroom. Besides keeping up with her studies, SIS final year student Sally Chin (@sallycsy) also took up a part-time internship at Microsoft as a Partner Technology Strategist. Her role entails working with customers and business partners to align their technology roadmaps with Microsoft-based solutions and technologies priorities, enabling them to realise the vision of digital transformation.
_ 
Gaining the internship experience under her belt has definitely helped Sally to take the first step into the corporate world. She has worked with a range of clients on real projects, and made meaningful connections with people along the way. She shares, ‘Whenever you run into any sticky situations, do not be afraid to reach out to people around you. When we’re open to learning from others, we benefit from their experience as well as our own.’ Coincidentally, even her mentor at work was an SIS alumnus!
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

We would like to extend our sincere gratitude to Jim Sarka and Johnson & Johnson team for their sponsorship and support for the ‘IS425 Managing Information Systems for Business Value’ course. 
_

It is important to understand theories of IT management and its best practices, and put them into practice by solving real life case problems holistically. Through IS425 course, our students had the opportunity to learn from the industry leaders, and apply the knowledge gained to propose IT Strategy that enables organisations to better exploit latest Technology (e.g. Cloud Computing, Mobile Computing or Social Computing) in delivering business value.

_

Click on the link to read the excellent testimony to our SMU students: https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6519213422926753792
_

SMU hosted the second episode of Perspectives Season 8 “Responsible Artificial Intelligence (A.I.): How to save humanity from the dark side of A.I.?” on 7 March 2019 which featured an esteemed panel of thought leaders including SIS Professor Pradeep Reddy Varakantham. 
_ 
The panel spoke on the potential of A.I., while addressing the audience’s concerns regarding the ethics of A.I., as well as the unintended consequences that came along with its rise. 
_ 
Watch the mediacast at smu.sg/responsible-ai
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

It’s a ‘Show-and-Tell’ at the SMT203 Smart City Systems and Management Poster Day! Our students majoring in the Smart-City Management and Technology programme were eager to share their innovative IT solutions and systems architecture to the public. 
_

Can you imagine everything you are in touch with today could have sensors collecting and transmitting data to the cloud. The network of connected things, or Internet of Things (IoT) interconnects all sorts of devices, enabling people to enjoy advanced connectivity and new conveniences. Some of the showcases include: real-time monitoring of laundry services, real-time queue data incorporating facial recognition API, smart attendance-taking using wifi signals, and integrated web application for facilities management. 
_

All in all, it was a great learning opportunity for the SIS community and public to exchange ideas on how to leverage the use of information and communication technologies (ICT) to develop smart cities. 
_

Our SIS Senior Year students are all prepped up for live demos and project showcases (also known as poster days) in the coming days. First off, we have the IS415 Geospatial Analytics and Applications Townhall Presentation which was held at the GeoWorks, an industry centre to promote geospatial innovation and competencies. 
_

In this globalising and competitive business environment, the value of location as a business measure is fast becoming an important consideration for organisation. Geospatial Analytics with its capability to visualise, analyse and model business information spatially is emerging as a location intelligence tool. Today, many kinds of industries are employing geospatial analytics as an integral part of their business processes. 
_
(Photo Credits: Sheryl Yeo @sherylovelleyeo)
_

The heat is on but Yixi (@yixii_) is glad she is not fighting this battle alone. 
_ 
She has recently concluded a series of events – the most recent one being SIS Finals Welfare Drive and Patron's Day 2019. Besides juggling academic projects and final submissions, Yixi has kick-started her summer commitments that includes the logistical planning for MetamorphoSIS Camp (@smu.metamorphosis - SIS Freshmen Orientation Camp) and SMU Broadcast & Entertainment (@smube) Voice Personality Hunt. 
_
Amid her busy schedules, hear what Yixi has to say about the diverse opportunities at SIS: “There are opportunities for every SIS student no matter where your interest lies. It could be something that is academic-related – for instance, joining Special Interest Groups such as Business Intelligence & Analytics (BIA) Club (@smu.bia) and Whitehats, help students meet like-minded individuals through workshop and activities. If you are an event enthusiast like me who wants to contribute back to the SIS community, being a part of the SMU EllipSIS (@smuellipsis) has been a great experience so far. The first event I participated was ExploreSIS 2018, an outreach day camp for Poly and JC students. As part of the organising committee, it was really satisfying seeing participants enjoying themselves through the coding workshop and games that we planned out for them. So don’t be afraid to step out of your comfort zone and pick up a new skill that you have always wanted to try!” _
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Meet fresh graduate Manfred (@abundanceofmanny) or affectionately known as ‘Manny’ to his friends.
.
Prior to joining SIS, he had no background in technology and programming, and he recalled it was one of the greatest worries he had back then as an incoming student. No doubt the journey of any SIS Student will not be a walk in the park, but Manny believes that approaching it with an open mind and a desire to learn will come a long way. He recounted how the school prepares and grooms their students not just in terms of academics and technical knowledge, but also the emphasis of soft skills that allow one to hit the ground running when they enter the workforce.
.
To gain the most of his experience in SIS, Manny joined the EllipSIS (@smuellipsis), a student representative body for the school. He was the Events Director for the 13th executive committee, and that stood him a good stead to host networking sessions, interact with companies and seek potential career opportunities. Besides that, Manny also attributed his achievement to Project HeartCode, a community service project dedicated to underprivileged youths of Singapore, giving them an opportunity to experience and pick up valuable technical skills like Web Development and Internet-of-Things (IoT). #smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

The digitisation of the law practice in Singapore is gathering momentum but do you know what it takes to digitise the legal sector?
.
On 16 March 2019, we co-organised ‘FLIP the Digital Switch’ Workshop with SMU School of Law (@sgsmusol). Professor Venky Shankararaman started the dialogue by sharing how technology has a transformative and disruptive effect in almost every industries which includes the legal sector. With the technological changes and opportunities brought upon by the deployment of artificial intelligence, we need to position ourselves to better understand the legal, regulatory and compliance landscape within which the technology operates.
.
Chief Operating Officer of Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) Mr. Paul Neo was invited to share with us the ways to establish a legal tech ecosystem through Future Law Innovation Programme (FLIP), an industry-wide initiative that aims to promote the adoption of technology by law firms. 
A guided discussion was then conducted with a case study on ‘Helping Law Firms FLIP the Digital Switch’, leading the students to understand that computing in law is very timely and future-relevant. Co-directors for the new Bachelor of Science (Computing & Law) degree programme Associate Professor Manoj Thulasidas and Associate Professor Lee Pey Won were in attendance to answer questions from the floor.
To learn more about our new Bachelor of Science (Computing & Law) degree programme, visit www.sis.smu.edu.sg/bsc-computing-law 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

It was an eventful weekend for the SMU Whitehacks Society! We were delighted by the overwhelming response from various Junior Colleges.

Cyberattacks are on the rise and have become more sophisticated, meaning that keeping data, software and hardware safe and secure is more important than ever. We were honored to have guest speakers from Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA), Government Technology Agency (GovTech), and Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT), to share with us the latest trends in cybersecurity landscape.
.
In the 2-day workshop, participants were guided through a few trainings on cybersecurity fundamentals and the know-hows of computing programming before breaking into huddles to work on a series of challenges. To some participants, it was their first experience dabbling into coding whereas there was also a fair share of them who already have a knack for web penetration testing.

Last but not least, a BIG thank you to the committee of SMU Whitehacks Society for the utmost effort in managing the event. Thank you to all the attendees for spending the weekend with us to experience the learning pedagogy and interact with our SIS students and faculty. We hope you find your inner hacker, and we look forward to seeing you again in our future events! 🤗
.
(Photo Credits: James Looi @jormasloot)
.
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #Cybersecurity

Last but not least, a BIG thank you to the committee of SMU Whitehacks Society for the utmost effort in managing the event. Thank you to all the attendees for spending the weekend with us to experience the learning pedagogy and interact with our SIS students and faculty. We hope you find your inner hacker, and we look forward to seeing you again in our future events! 🤗
.
(Photo Credits: James Looi @jormasloot)
.
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #Cybersecurity

It was an eventful weekend for the SMU Whitehacks Society! We were delighted by the overwhelming response from various Junior Colleges.

Cyberattacks are on the rise and have become more sophisticated, meaning that keeping data, software and hardware safe and secure is more important than ever. We were honored to have guest speakers from Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA), Government Technology Agency (GovTech), and Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT), to share with us the latest trends in cybersecurity landscape.
.
In the 2-day workshop, participants were guided through a few trainings on cybersecurity fundamentals and the know-hows of computing programming before breaking into huddles to work on a series of challenges. To some participants, it was their first experience dabbling into coding whereas there was also a fair share of them who already have a knack for web penetration testing.

Last but not least, a BIG thank you to the committee of SMU Whitehacks Society for the utmost effort in managing the event. Thank you to all the attendees for spending the weekend with us to experience the learning pedagogy and interact with our SIS students and faculty. We hope you find your inner hacker, and we look forward to seeing you again in our future events! 🤗
.

TGIF, we are drawing closer to the end of week 10! We know how jam-packed your schedules are but be sure to make time to unwind.
.
All work and no play makes jack a dumb boy, but that doesn’t apply to SIS Freshie James Looi (@jormasloot). Although he is preoccupied with upcoming project submissions and presentations, that doesn’t deter him from taking the time to unplug and recharge. During his leisure time, James engages in activities hosted by SMUX Skating team (@smuxskating) where they will have weekly skating sessions at various dinner spots all over Singapore. 
_
Besides that, James is also in the executive committee for SMU Whitehat Society, a special interest group founded by a group of students who are passionate about cybersecurity. At the moment, he is working on the finishing touches for Whitehacks 2019, an outreach program for the Junior College students, and that is happening this weekend!
.
Press on and do stay tuned for more updates~
.
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

The word is out~ SMU sent out more than 250 graduates from the School of Information Systems (SIS) each year between 2016 and 2018 with the figure set to increase in the future!
_

In view of the rising demand for graduates trained in areas such as artificial intelligence, data analytics and cybersecurity, SIS has announced two new computing related degree programmes: Bachelor of Science (Computer Science) and Bachelor of Science (Computing and Law) which will be launching this year and in 2020 respectively. 
_ 
SIS Dean Professor Pang Hwee Hwa said, “Computing is reaching every industry, creating new jobs and changing existing ones. Companies and public agencies are employing digital technology to transform their business models and processes.”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

‘Do I need to have IT background? Do I need to have prior knowledge in coding?’ - These are some of the most pressing questions we get from prospective students and parents. 
_

Fret not, SIS Freshie Quok Juin (@upupawaytoday) has something to share to dispel your concern: “Everyone has to start somewhere and many people I know came into SIS without any coding background and are doing very well now so there really isn’t much to worry about! 
_

One of the best things about SIS is the highly collaborative learning culture. Don’t worry too much about not being able to code as there will be peers and faculty around to help you along the way. People of different project groups will even come together to discuss the best way to complete the assignment and everyone will have a chance to learn through the insights shared.” #smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Mobile apps have brought so much convenience and fun into our lives. From route planning to grocery shopping, reserving flights and hiring bicycles, to the action games we play to pass the time on public transport.
But have we become so seduced with the seemingly limitless functionality of mobile apps that we’re overlooking their fundamental downside—the potential compromise of our security and privacy?
_

Read more of Associate Professor Gao Debin's commentary at smu.sg/functionality-privacy-mobile-app
 _

Happy hump day and a warm welcome to students from Anglo-Chinese School (Independent)! Thanks for making the time to join us for the Learning Journey. Hope you have gained insights from Assistant Professor Kyong's sharing of the importance of computing, and get to know how our undergraduate offerings at SIS can equip you to create the digital future. ⚡ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Our BSc (Computer Science) Programme Director Hady recently conducted a workshop on “Supervised Learning via Linear and Logistic Regressions” to a group of Year 6 students from NUS High School. 
_
Supervised Learning, in the context of Artificial Intelligence, is a type of machine learning algorithm that uses a known dataset to make predictions. To better grasp the concept, students were taught how to apply the various types of learning paradigms such as ‘Regression’ and ‘Classification’ through a few tutorial exercises on Scikit-learn.
_
The 3-hour workshop was concluded with a competition, which involves students getting their hands to test the datasets, train the models and make predictions of the rental prices of properties in Singapore. 
_
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw

Good news to start off the week! Team TankBellCurve has emerged as the runner-up in EY Asia-Pacific Cyber Challenge 2019!
_

The team of 4 comprising of members across three different batches of SIS cohorts are united by the interest in Cybersecurity. 
_ 
Here’s what they have to say: “The competition was both exhilarating and challenging. Over the course of the hackathon, we encountered subjects which we are not familiar with. We struggled and had to learn along the way. We had to assimilate knowledge quick and apply them in the right context. It was against all odds, in which we matured. It was never about winning but rather the learning process. 
One of the key takeaways is never give up. It was through sheer tenacity which allowed us to progress through the competition. We are thankful for the overseas experience and would like to express our deepest gratitude to SIS, for all the support and opportunities given to us in this cyber hackathon organised by @eysgcareers”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #Cybersecurity

_

Best of luck guys, we will be rooting for you! 👍
_

Kudos to our class of 2018! 
According to the recent Joint Graduate Employment Survey, SIS graduates show strong career prospects and have jobs relevant to their course of study! In particular, SIS graduates earned the highest salary with a mean monthly salary of $4,160, a 3.6 per cent increase over the 2017 cohort ($4,014). (Photo Credits: Tay Jingying @_jingying)

description:
SIS Alumna Jing Ying (@_jingying) is experiencing a new lease of life! Besides switching to a brand new phone, the transition from a fresh graduate to a working professional has been pretty good for her. She is now a technology analyst at the Bank of America Merrill Lynch. She added that apart from the technical knowledge gained in school, the curriculum has boosted her analytical thinking, resilience and interpersonal skills, which are crucial in the real world. 
_ 
Jing Ying said: “I tell my friends that we're quite lucky to graduate at the right time, when a lot of companies are using technology to improve systems and work processes, and they need IT graduates.”
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #SIS_Smiles #SISAlumni

WhiteHacks is an annual outreach event hosted by Whitehats Society of SMU, and serves as an introductory competition benchmarking cybersecurity potential. It is delivered in a series of challenges which the participating teams have to solve to claim points. The team with the highest score at the end will be the grand winner for the competition.
_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Techology #ComputingandLaw #Innovation #ComputerScience

“Unlearn, Relearn and Learning to Learn.” - This is one of the key takeaways for Jacey Teoh, a student from the Eunoia Junior College who attended Women in Tech held on 25 January 2019. 
_

One of the most exciting aspects of having a career in information technology is how it overlaps with so many industries. This means the possibilities are endless, you can find work in just about any sector you like. However, while the digital revolution is in full swing, there is a serious shortage of women working in tech companies. 
_

A panel discussion on ‘Women Making a Difference with Technology’ brings to light the under-representation of women and how it is pertinent to empower them in technology from the classroom to the boardroom.
_

Jacey also recounted her experience of building MRT stations and mapping distance routes by plotting a Voronoi diagram in the hands-on workshop conducted by Associate Professor Zheng Baihua.
_

Read more:
https://eunoiaorigin.com/2019/01/28/smu-women-in-tech-talk/

The article was published in the Eunoia Junior College Press – The Origin (28 January 2019).
_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #ComputerScience #ComputingandLaw #Technology #Innovation
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
SIS Faculty Feature. Assistant Professor Subhajit Datta started 2019 with us at SIS.  I initially thought his name was spelled like Data from Star Trek. He probably gets that a lot.  After he spelled it out, he told me his website name is www.dattas.net I don’t think anyone can top that when you see which course he’s teaching.
.
Q: What are you teaching this term at SIS?
A: Data Management, a core course for first year students in Information Systems major.
.
Q: What do you do in your free time?
A: I write. I’ve written 2 books, the first was on large scale software systems - Metrics-Driven Enterprise Software Development.  The second was a college textbook on Software Engineering.  I’m working on my third book on making sense of data, how we can be more informed users of information. The book is a bridge between popular science and a textbook. There will be some hands-on, skills-based tools like R programming.
.
Q: What sports do you play?
A: Cricket.  I don’t really play these days but I still watch cricket.
.
Q: What’s your favourite film genre?
A: I prefer to read compared to movies or Netflix because I have too much screen time daily.
.
Q: How would your friends describe you?
A: I consciously seek out friends who are different from me. In life, all the interesting things come from the weak ties we have.  This is based on a paper The Strength of Weak Ties” by Mark S. Granovetter. .
Q: What would you do even if you weren’t paid any money?
A: Write!  Books have important appeal in reaching out to people, especially un-like-minded people.
.
Thanks Subhajit!  Welcome again to SIS. 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #computingatSMU #smartcitymanagment #faculty #datamanagement #softwareengineering #softwarearchitecture #socialcomputing #bigscholarlydata #cyberphyiscalsystems
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Prof Venky was on the panel discussion for “Cloud Computing for Industry 4.0 at Singapore Computer Society Cloud Conference 2019. This year’s conference explored current and emerging topics in the cloud landscape and the impact of analytics, machine learning, AI, IoT and cybersecurity. Seated next to Venky is fellow panel discussion member Mr Lyonel Cha, Director, Infra-services, Integrated Health Information Systems.

location: Singapore

description:
SIS Faculty Feature. Upon entering Senior Lecturer Siaw Ling’s office, one is struck by how colourful it is, from the items on her desk to the balloons she saved from an event which lined her otherwise empty bookcases.  After all, she has just joined SIS less than 2 months ago. I shot the usual questions to Siaw Ling and I was pleasantly surprised when I didn’t get the usual answers back.
.
Q: What do you teach at SIS?
A: Analytics Foundation and Digital Analytics Technology, to year 2s and 3s.
.
Q: I see lots of colours. Tell me about the balloons on the bookshelves.
A: (Laughs) they’re from a Digital Analytics event by Google. The helium balloons slowly sank to the ground. Colours brighten up my office and the balloon shape ties in with data visualisation where I tell stories with charts.
.
Q: What do you do in your free time?
A: I like to be outdoors with my family at parks, cycling through park connectors.
.
Q: What would you do even if you weren’t paid any money?
A: Draw!  I draw black and white pictures with pencil and pen.  My favourite comic is Calvin and Hobbes.
.
Q: Complete this sentence - “At home, I am the go-to person for…”
A: My kids always ask me to help them with their art. They always ask me, do these colours go together?  I am also the go-to person for fashion styling because I like recommending outfit combinations to my kids. Maybe I would be a fashion stylist if I wasn’t a lecturer?! (Laughs).
.
Q: What workouts do you do to stay fit and healthy?
A: Walking.
.
The interview ended with talk about the weekly brisk group which a few SIS staff join. Welcome again to SIS, Siaw Ling! 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #computingatSMU #smartcitymanagment #faculty #datascience #textanalytics #socialmediaanalytics #urbanandsocialanalytics
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
It was a full-house at Women in Tech. The keynote was delivered by our guest-of-honour Ms Jessica Tan (Member of Parliament, East Coast GRC and Director, Group Commercial, Raffles Medical Group). She wove personal anecdotes with interesting studies and held the room’s attention with facts like how it’ll take 108 years for men and women to reach pay and economic parity and how only 22% of AI professionals in the world are women compared to 78% who are men [2018 Global Gender Gap Report by World Economic Forum if you want to read more]. During the panel discussion on Women Making a Difference with Technology, questions from the audience were answered thoughtfully from nuanced perspectives by Jessica, Asst Prof Kyong, Asst Prof Hwee Xian and alumnae Chloe and Shermin.  Assoc Prof Baihua led participants with a hands-on workshop with the question “How to find your nearest MRT station” and introduced the workshop with Voronoi Diagram.  Parting shot - the advice from Women in Tech is applicable to all: it’s about the competencies you bring, not whether you’re male or female, young or old.  There’s stuff that never gets old - the ability to work together with others, communicate your ideas, applying what you’ve learnt, applying technology to human issues. 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #informationsystems #smartcitymanagment #computerscience
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
SIS Faculty Feature. Asst Prof Shar Lwin Khin joined us recently and we popped a few quick questions to get to know him a little better.
.
Q: What do you teach at SIS?
A: Web Application Development and Foundations of Cybersecurity.
.
Q: You’re new at SIS, made any friends yet?
A: David Lo (short pause) I know from before I joined SIS, Subhajit who is also new and Yingjiu, I work with.
.
Q: What is your favourite film genre and do you follow any series?
A: Sci Fi.  I follow Black Mirror on Netflix but I try not to start because it’s difficult to stop.  I like Japanese Anime also and I've been watching Naruto for more than 20 years.
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Q: What do people say you’re good at?
A: I’m friendly and hope the students find me approachable. I like to create a friendly environment.
.
Q: What workouts do you do to stay fit and healthy?
A: Walking, swimming, stretching. I haven’t checked out the swimming pool, I hear there’s one at Admin building. I don’t have time to workout and I spend a lot of time sitting and working so I take short breaks to stretch and do some push ups and crunches (gestures to workout mat at the corner of his office and we proceeded to talk about effective bodyweight exercise moves).
.⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Welcome again to SIS, Shar!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #computingatSMU #smartcitymanagment #cybersecurity #coding #programming #faculty

description:
Yeow Leong showed junior college teachers how he has been implementing flipped learning in his programming course in terms of what he does and what students do before, during and after class.  Yeow Leong was candid about the challenges he faces, one of which is the effort to record teaching videos and finding that sweet spot of good enough which lies somewhere between getting the right dose of content out in a 5-minute clip and curbing perfectionist tendencies. The other challenge he faces? Educating students to prepare for class and gave the analogy of an Ah Long where he chases students individually into action. During his presentation, he managed to find a moment of levity to strike ridiculous poses for the camera and the seminar room exploded with laughter.  We will officially deny possession of these said photos. 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #computingatSMU 
#pedagogy #flippedlearning #flippedclassroom #Python
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Prof Kar Way held up goodies to get class discussion going at today's Learning Journey with National Junior College. Earlier, students were given a comic strip on urban innovations then split into smaller groups for discussion on data required and suggestions for improvement. Students rated other groups on their ideas and re-grouped for class discussion. Kar Way showed students smart city examples in the form of job roles and internships before handing over the floor to SIS students Vinnie, Debbie and Patrick who added their respective layers of experience on the caring and friendly culture at SIS, financial assistance available, overseas study missions and internships.

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #smartcitymanagement #studentlife
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Best IS480 Video 2.
_

Homecoming: The project aims to revamp HOME's casework management system. It will make case and worker management easier by effectively categorising sections of the case, and filtering out important and useful information for caseworkers. Various types of notifications will allow relevant caseworkers to stay updated. The CMS will also provide useful insights about the cases through data driven visualisation.

Watch the pitch video: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mKWmoqG8JdQ&index=8&list=PLpkm5DKJfGJz08HuLR0x2pRQlpf0_okdy 
_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #StudentLife
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Best IS480 Technical Innovation & Best IS480 Video 1.
_

Kaki&Kin: The data driven approach to train a chatbot is a tedious and time consuming manual process. The team has developed a semi-automatic pipeline to reduce the effort and time taken for data-driven chatbot training through Automatic Intent Generation that can respond more closely to end-user intentions. 
Watch the pitch video: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ezmNwu6GtcE&list=PLpkm5DKJfGJz08HuLR0x2pRQlpf0_okdy&index=34

_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #StudentLife
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Best IS480 Value to Sponsor.
_

Onken Egg: A project that allows people to skip the queues through our same-day preordering system and E-TopUp. Apart from the convenience, there’s also a Loyalty system where customers can earn points, complete tasks and refer friends for points and redeem rewards. Orders are sent to Order Management Dashboard (iPad). Admin Dashboard also has fully customisable functions to control EVERYTHING in the web app. 
Watch the pitch video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7peNatsKJWQ&list=PLpkm5DKJfGJz08HuLR0x2pRQlpf0_okdy&index=17

_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #StudentLife
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Best IS480 Project Management.
_

Team Meraki: For Businesses, the conversion rates (of views to action) for articles or videos is hard to keep track of. You can tell the virality but information that businesses thrives on in today's data centric society is missing. Icarius gives an extra push to provide objectives-centered advertising by providing content creators with an platform to create content and track Action-Oriented Metric.

Watch the pitch video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YIU-DteKdqg&index=14&list=PLpkm5DKJfGJz08HuLR0x2pRQlpf0_okdy&t=0s

_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #StudentLife
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Best IS480 Project.
_

Internet Explorers: A project that aims to utilise Internet-Of-Things (IoT) technologies to build a full-fledged live cloud system to best improve the efficiency of operations and increase the quality of healthcare provided to the semi-independent elderlies at St. Bernadette Lifestyle Village, which is an Assisted Living Facility (ALF). Watch the pitch video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QaGnB7TCX1s&list=PLpkm5DKJfGJz08HuLR0x2pRQlpf0_okdy&index=9

_ 
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #StudentLife
location: SMU School of Computing and Information Systems

description:
Put on your thinking cap and take a step closer to the real working world! 
_

IS480 is a final year project that requires students, in teams of 4-6 members, to provide innovative solutions to address business-IT problems or improve real corporate clients’ business operations. It serves as a springboard for undergraduates to develop technology deliverable, showcase their project management skills, and to learn valuable skills out of curriculum.

The class started this term with the prize presentation of the award winners from the previous semester. The awardees were also invited to share their exciting projects and greatest takeaways with their juniors.
_

Learn more about IS480 and don’t forget to subscribe to our YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLpkm5DKJfGJz08HuLR0x2pRQlpf0_okdy 
_

#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #InformationSystems #SmartCityManagement #Technology #Innovation #ComputerScience #StudentLife

description:
Poly and JC students were introduced to SIS programmes - IS degree Major in IS, IS degree Major in SMT, CS degree. Alumni Crys and Jonathan joined us and students went on a school tour of SMU campus. Students were divided into 2 groups for Python coding workshops with Benjamin leading one group and Eli leading another. description:
The third and final installment of Zero to Hero - Cybersecurity Day for JC and Poly students. Security and Threats in the Cyber World, covered by Tan Shu Ren, Manager (Cybersecurity) of the Centre for Strategic Infocomm Technologies (CSIT). As an alumnus of SIS, we took the opportunity to hand Shu Ren his very own Cody the Owl for care and feeding.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Prof Xuhua went through the basics of information security including encryption, message authentication and software vulnerabilities then led a hands-on session on cryptography.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
SIS current students Dingyao and Cher Boon from SIS Special Interest Group White Hats related their student life experience with participants.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
#smusis #SchoolofInformationSystems #ComputingatSMU #informationsecurity #cybersecurity
